number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												Game Dev Tycoon is a casual management sim around running your own game company.  The game has a simple but charming asthetic and follows the story of gaming from the early boom of the 80's to the modern day.  Making decisions on  the theme and design of your game and managing your staff are early challenges.  Later you will train staff, market your games and even develop your own console.The main drawback of the game is the weakness of the core development mechanics.  As you are required to use sliders to decide on the main areas to focus on for each game.  The preset combination that determines what reviewers deem "a good game" is often a mystery to you until you fail.  With a lack of detailed information of why your game failed its easy to become frustrated by this core mechanic.  This can be seen by the huge number of guides available on how to win the game, at this point you might as well be playing "spreadsheet the game". Overall, i'd say the games pro's outweigh its somewhat shallow mechanics.  If you can pick this one up on sale for under a fiver I'd give this one a somewhat half-hearted reccomendation.

You develope through 35 years of gaming industry, devolping (hopefully) the milestone games, everybody loves. At the start it seems so easy, but going on, it gets so hard.+ Superb Easter Eggs (For Gamers only)+ Just pure Fun, if you enjoy Simulations/Strategy and a bit of RPGCons- Sometimes frustrating when you invest millions in creating a game, and everything seems rght, but it turns out to be average or a flop- You will loose all your spare time, because it is a so addicting game :D

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Nostalgia and a fun concept can't overcome serious misteps in the game's mechanics.  Ambiguity in the feedback will have you scratching your head as you attempt to connect decisions you make in the development cycle to the resulting game reviews and scores.  At times you will struggle to understand what tradeoffs, if any, are tied to your choices.  If, out of frustration, you turn to online information in your attempt to better understand how the game calculates failure and success, you'll only increase your disappointment, since, for some inexplicable reason, the developers decided that success in Game Dev Tycoon should not be based on making the best game possible each development cycle, but rather on creating games that are only marginally better than your previous one.  That's right.  A surefire way to undermine your ability to get good reviews on future games is to make your current one too much fun.Apparently, the developers of Game Dev Tycoon took that strategy to heart.  Their chosen core mechanic will keep a game with plenty of potential from ever being too much fun.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
  Game Dev Tycoon.Developer: Greenheart GamesPublisher: Greenheart GamesReleased: April 28, 2013   Summary:  Game Dev Tycoon is a business simulation game in which you replay the history of the gaming industry by starting your own video game development company in the 80s. Create best selling games. Research new technologies and invent new game types. Become the leader of the market and gain worldwide fans. Game Dev Tycoon is a great casual game, and for the price I really can't complain. It's an indie endeavor, and while it doesn't achieve great technological marks it is very entertaining and will keep you occupied for hours (unless you pirated it! Shame!) as you progress through the different levels of the game. The mechanics can be a little obscure at first, but once you master managing your staff and achieving balance it becomes much easier to produce hits and dig into the deeper end-game level content. I could play this game for hours and days. Hard to master as it has a unique mathematical algorithm to rate the games you make based on a number of different variety of mixing. ~GildaTheGriffin. content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Game Dev Tycoon is a fun and cute game, and I really enjoyed my two playthroughs. I will recommend it to anyone that likes simulation management games.  The game is summed up well in the descriptions, so this review will more be my experience with the game and nitpicks.I haven't fully figured out why some of my games fail, even though they were a great combination, and others just explode on the market. Which lead to me doing significantly worse during my second playthrough. The bank lending me money at least once during almost every stage of the game, but it was actually a bit funnier and more challenging when I constantly fluctuated between hits and failures. The last phase was way to easy on my first playthrough, because I had no specialists in my team, so I didn't go into the labs. But even though spending money on discovering things in the lab and building consoles made it more challenging, it made it way more fun, and on my last years of my second playthrough I had the second generation of my console out and a hit MMORPG.The reviewers in the game can be jerks. On my first playthrough I made a lot of hit games, and there were constantly two of them that switched between giving me 9, so I got 9.75 instead of perfect ten. Felt like they were just trying to keep me from getting the achievement. :( And like I said, I got worse at the game the second time, so I'm probably never gonna get that achievement.There is a lot in the game, but it never gets too complex to manage. The game that comes closest to the same experience of playing for me is probably the sims series. Where you just keep playing and there is so much to do, and a lot of minor variables, but it is all easily presented and managable. However... It suffers from the same problem that the main Sims games have for, which is that there are no natural "exit points" no real quests, so it can be hard to stop before you reach the end and can lead to game burnout eventurally. (I know sims doesn't have an end, but this game kinda has one where you get your end score) You could argue every time you finish a game within the game it is an exit, but then you get the reviews, then it goes on the market, and while it is on the market or before it gets reviewed you put your team on the task of developing, reaching, or training something else. So there is no place where the game feels like it is a natural place to take a break I would love if they make a sequel or spinoff game where they include some kind of quests or in game objectives beyond the achievements.But it is still a topranking simulation game, and I am glad I bought it. 9.75/10

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a game that can be challenging at first, but is extremely satisfying once you get farther. When I started out, I really hated how all my games that I thought would be really cool came out with crappy reviews and awful sales. I didn't like that to the point where I decided to use guides on the internet to try and improve my games. I don't regret doing it, because I really hated playing the game without it, and it helped a lot. One thing about this game is that it's really hard to get started. It takes a long time to get all the hints and then to know how to use them to the best, and I still haven't unlocked all of them after creating Game Reports after every game. I've still been continuing to use guides, and it's been improving the game for me.Another thing I don't like is how random the game reviewing system still feels. Sometimes I will follow the hints and guides exactly (and since I'm using the hints too, it's not just the guide being wrong) and the game will still come out with a 6-7 review.I think it can be challenging to determine what I should be using my research points on, and even more so as I'm getting farther in the game and I need to start having specialists in certain areas. I know this is something you have to learn on your own, but this is a situation similar to getting the topic-genre-gaming device right where it's not worth the effort to look into, and it's a nice thing to know in advance.The one thing in the game that has bothered me the most, however, is the lack of a reminder to name your game. My biggest issue for a really long time was forgetting to name my games, and I know you aren't reminded to do that because it affects the reviewing process, but I feel like if you got a little reminder to name a game it could go a long way. In my opinion, it doesn't even make sense to let a game called "Game #38" onto the market anyways, it doesn't sound like a game at all. The way I finally got myself to remember to name games is by being in a skype call with my friends and getting them to select from a bunch of options to develop my games, and then getting them to name it to make it more fun. Other than that, more than half my games have been unnamed.However, this game is still really fun. Where it does have it's downsides, there is still something that keeps me playing. One thing might simply be that I haven't completed the game yet, or that I want to get more achievements, but one of my favourite things is easily how satisfying it is to make a successful game. The income rate is amazing, I love seeing my money increase, and every time I see a "10" on the initial reviews I know I'm in for a treat.Overall, this game may not be worth a full $10, but if it's ever on sale at a price of less than $5 I easily recommend that you get it. It has some faults, but when you succeed it's easily worth the sadness of previous failures.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Fun little management sim with some limitations. Although enjoyable for a while, there is not a lot of depth in the gameplay. You basically choose a combination of genres/topics/platforms for a game, researching and improving your skills along your journey to make more complex (and hopefully better rating) games. The better the ratings after release, the more money you get to grow your business. You will progress from your garage to corporate office and hire employees along the way. There are also a few other basic things you can do like training employees, research new tech, marketing & sign with publishers. Game Dev Tycoon uses some play-on-words to 'loosely' follow historical references to progress the game through release of new consoles and hardware to modern day.Gaming combinations that might be popular in real life don't necessarily correspond to a good game in Game Dev Tycoon and there are also some strange ones you can choose. Mastering the game really come down to memorising what combos works (through trial & error) which starts to detract from the experience after you have played a few games. What you have learned in previous games can be kept for future games to help out. I was really hoping there would be more strategic depth and more varied tactics you could use to change the game outcome and wanted to be able to go all the way to an EA or Valve type of game dev. Regrettably, you can only have 6 employees and is not designed to be open ended with a fixed end point finalising your game. A game on making games is a great concept. Fulfilling many gamers fantasies of developing their own unique games, but this needs more content, more detail, much more customisation & strategy to become something special. Game Dev Tycoon is still a decent bit of fun, despite it being simplistic and with limited replayability so gets the 'Thumbs Up' from me!If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												What is there to say that hasn't already been said? Of the "Tycoon" style simulation games, this one certainly isn't the best. However, if you have a deep love of video games, the gaming economy, and the business aspect of video games you'll find this game quite entertaining. Not to mention, those who love management to begin with. There is so much to micromanage in this game, I actually found it hard to find time for everything (although I'm not a huge fan of management games, so that may just be me.)Pros:- Lots of freedom- Great walkthrough of the "history of gaming"- cute art- fun writing (for the few story aspects)- tons of researchable topics and technologies- great system allowing for combination of genress and game topics- diverse character modelsCons- music gets old, limited music options- reporters ask the the same questions over and over again- sometimes, critics' reviews feel very random- doesn't feel very competitive when you never get to see sales of rival companies

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game was fun for a few hours. It may have been luck, or maybe it was my long love of RPGs, but I hit one out of the park and moved out of the garage after a couple of games. After that the game went stagnant:* The history of gaming unfurls before you, in exactly the same way every time. It's cute to see the "PlaySystem" launch or to see the "Gameling" dominate mobile gaming for a long time, but putting a real-world analogue into the game is inviting meta analysis. I'd rather see random platforms and performance for an alternate universe feel.* Once you get into the groove, the game becomes exactly as much fun as Microsoft Excel.* The game tries to punish you for making the same game over and over, yet doesn't seem to encourage experimentation and risk-taking. I'm sure it's to do with my own playstyle and missteps, but my company was always one game away from bankruptcy, which made it tough to try that mBox Lawyer RPG instead of another iteration of Vampire RPG for the PC.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I was originally given this game as a gift by a good friend of mine.Usually, I don't tend to delve into Steam at all, I have been pro-console all of my life, until I played this game. After being a fan of simulation games on consoles (with the occasional PC port here and there) such as Football Manager, The Sims, Rollercoaster Tycoon to name but a few, I was skeptical going into playing this game, but boy was I wrong. The game starts you out in a lowly garage with a start-up cost of 70K. Now to some, that is a lot of money to start of with in any game, (well, from your Garage at least) but taking into consideration the fact that it takes 8K a month to run the costs of everything, we can say it is justifiable. You also have the start-up option of running your games from a G64 (a hat-tip to the Commodore 64, which was obviously name changed due to copyright reasons) or the PC. There are also five game topics you are given to start-up with such as, Fantasy, Dungeon, Sports, Surgery and Military, but these can vary when starting up a new game, you could even get topics like Alien or UFO! It all depends on what the computer decides it wants you to have at the beginning. You are able to unlock further topics by 'researching' them with the points you have accumulated for creating games, these points can also be spent on other things such as, improving the games engine, sound (or later on in the game) quests, among others. You are also given the option of choosing which marketable area you would like your game to go to once you have unlocked the 'Marketing' option once you have released enough titles to warrant these, or enough time has elapsed, there are split into three categories E (Everyone), M (Mature) or Y (Young), I only ever used the 'Everyone' option, but that worked well on every topic I did indeed choose. As time progresses, you and the consoles around you do too, shortly into the game, the 'Ninvendo TES' (a homage to the Nintendo NES) comes onto the market, (which in some respects is a good thing as the consoles evolve, just like they did in real life) the G64 comes off of the market and later on you are introduced to other consoles, such as the in-game SNES, Master System, Playstation and eventually, the PS5 (the in-game names now allude me, I apologise). Once you have reached the 1Million currency mark with creating games, you are offered to move into a bigger office, with much more space (I would personally advise this to be taken when you have about 10-20M in the bank, as you'll more than likely go bankrupt if you take this option too early on in the game). You accumulate the money by releasing good, titles (ratings with 7/8s are what I was getting until I released a Racing Simulator game which gave me 9s) which are rated by four gaming magazines. Now, if you're going for the achievements of 'Perfect Score' you are more than likely going to get it during the larger rooms, not necessarily in the Garage, I haven't personally seen it happen as of typing this.Now, you should have enough money to advance to the next room, where you can employ people, a maximum of four is allowed in this room and this is where the fun starts to really kick in. You have the option of training them once you have employed them, if this doesn't happen, you will be stuck producing the same scored games for a while, also, switch up the genres once in a while too, its amazing how much a well researched game topic can jump from 4s to about 8s from the last time a game was made and a word to the wise, DO NOT make two game genres the same one after another, your fans will not like that and would probably end up losing some as well as money. I could go further into the last room, but that is something that you need to find out for yourself to play, create your own consoles, release an AAA title and have up to 6 staff members, that is all I am going to let you in on there!All in all, I would recommend this game to anybody and everybody and I am ashamed I never bought this myself and waited until I mentioned it to a friend to buy it for me as a gift, otherwise I would have bought it day one. 11/10. Loved every minute of it and the achievements leave you wanting more.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												It is easy to learn how to play Game Dev Tycoon; figuring out how to maximise profits is a bit more difficult. You have to mix and match different genres to find what sells best. After you figure out what genres work well, you have to target an audience for your game. Then you have to decide what your going to work on more: gameplay or story? Dialogue or level design? Graphics or world design? In the end, all of your choices will be what makes or breaks your game.Game Dev Tycoon is definitely in my top ten favorite games. I have played many playthroughs and enjoyed each one. It is also relaxing to watch all of the design and tech bubbles float to the top of the screen. I would recommend Game Dev Tycoon to any of my friends.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I put a great many hours into Kevin Toms' Software Star. I would invariably do extremely poorly, because using Hype was basically lying about how good your game was, wasn't it? That wouldn't be right. Tell the people the truth, they're only going to find out when someone hands them your game on a C90.But I digress. THIS game is the same basic idea (Sim Games Dev) with a really pleasant presentation. Hire and fire, develop game features and engines, churn out cash-in franchises as often as you dare and throw as much marketing money around as possible to push you over the top.It's essentially a toy for people who like games and gaming and the games industry and think about them a lot.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Gave Dev Tycoon lets you start your own company as a game developer. At first you start small in your garage, but as you make more and more successful games you can change offices, hire staff, and upgrade your skills through training. While it is a simple concept, game dev tycoon is promising, in the sense that it keeps adding variety to your game making process and letting you make more complex choices as you progress through the game. The graphics and music are quite simple and not really an asset to be discussed for this game. Its gameplay largely consists of you adjusting sliders so as to decide which concepts you are going to give emphasis on while creating each game, such as sound, graphics etc. You also witness the emergence and disappearance of several types of consoles and decide where to release each game, while also keeping in mind the market trends. The most prominent problem with this game, would be that you get to decide based on trial and error more often than not, and the feedback you get about the choices you made is not entirely helpful for you to choose better next time around. The existance of a wiki for this game has made it so that tons of people end up following just that, since it is way less frustrating to progress in this way. Overall, I wouldnt call game dev tycoon a bad game, but a game that could use some polishing to shine.+ great genre/topic/platform variety+ easy to grasp, hard to master- game choice feedback is vague

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												In all honesty there have been few 'Tycoon' games I like.  I bought this title because, I want to be a game developer.   The Premise of Game Dev Tycoon is, rather... well you are a game developer, and you play through the ages and generations of video games, starting from the NES era of gaming and work your way through today.The game progresses from you working alone in a garage, to a small team in a smaller office, to a massive corprate headquaters where you can pump out tripple A titles.So the question is thus, what about the game development part.  Well basicly there are three parts to game development, and three sliders per part.  Pending on Genre and type of game pends on how the sliders need to be set, where you need to spend your time and resources into making a good game.  Then you watch bubbles (With one of the most addictive sound effects) float up into a compleation bar.  That's about it.So in all honesty theres not much to gameplay at all, its simple, it's straight foward, and I quite like it, personally after hashing out a few sequals it makes you think on what you are creating, and has given me some neat ideas for games just because I kept pumping out sucessful sequals in this game.So All in All, I recomend this game, it is a handy timewaster, it is fun in it's own way, a little addictive, and is easy on the CPU.  So by all means give it a whirl.Note to the Developer: I think a demo of the first garage era would go a long way for this game to get more people to play it.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I was very excited to see this game come on sale recently, as I'd had my eye on it for some time. It is a very good game at first, despite a lack of polish here and there (inexplicable error message on first launch, the odd spelling/grammatical error in the dialog boxes, etc.). Therefore, I think it is worth getting on sale.However, it quickly gets old; mostly, I think, due to its cyclical mechanics and unrealistic time scale. As a simulator, these factors take away from the experience. For example, a game may take as little as several months to produce, bug-free, and is "on the market" for only a short time, even if it is a smash hit. The result is that you must constantly churn out game after game, whereas I naturally tend towards producing 3 or 4 titles that I can release the next installments for periodically -- not unlike real life. By the fourth year, having produced several hits and sitting at a cool 4.4 million, with a new office, an employee, and lots to research/train, I said to myself, "Just 31 years to go...ugh".So that's basically it for me. Something tells me that I stopped right when the game was about to get its second wind. I've no doubt that I'll pick it up from time to time to tinker with. It is well made and fun as far as it goes, just not something I can really sink my teeth into and feel satisfied. I'm flagging this review with a "Not recommended" just so that people can see an alternate perspective amongst the sea of absolutely glowing reviews. I'm interested to see what Greenheart Games will come up with next. :)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												[Full review of Game Dev Tycoon]Graphics:The graphics are very basic but they're clean and go well with this type of indie game. However, I feel like the game would've benefitted from more customization options for characters and the actual businesses. The graphics are so simplistic that more customization probably would've been pretty easy to pull off, making it seem a little lazy. - 7/10Audio:I like the music but I'm pretty sure that there's only 2 or 3 tracks playing on a loop so it can get pretty repetitive if you play for hours at a time. The music that is there fits the game well though, I just wish there was more of it. - 7/10Gameplay:The gameplay is really unique and can get pretty complex, providing a great challenge for both new and veteran players. However, it can be a bit difficult to tell what was bad about certain games because specifics are not always offered and the review system has always seemed a little off to me.I think that there are enough unique aspects to keep the game engaging though, and you're able to hire on new team members to attempt larger games in the later stages, which are the most fun imo. - 8/10Story:There really isn't one. It's a typical tycoon game where the story is just "one day you decided to start making video games and become successful" - nothing too deep. The cool thing is that you start making games in the very early stages of the gaming industry so you actually get to see all the “now-legendary” consoles released and make games for them! It can be pretty funny too since the developers had to come up with some pretty creative names in order to avoid copyright. A story isn’t really necessary in these types of games but it would’ve been nice to see your company presented with various choices or something. - 7/10Replayability:Like any tycoon game, you can play as many times as you want and it can also be pretty easy to fail so you might even have to start over a couple of times anyway. The beauty of a simple concept like this is that it never really gets old and I, personally, keep the game installed on my PC just in case I'm ever in the mood to play it, which is pretty often honestly. I’ve completed the game a couple of times now and it’s always fun to play, just don’t expect a totally new experience each time you play it. - 8/10Overall:Overall I was very impressed with this tycoon game, especially considering the fact that it was made by a 2 man team and was released for the extremely low price of $10. There’s a lot of fun strategy to be had here, but only if you like the tycoon genre, and only if you actually have an interest in the gaming industry. If you’re bored by either of those two things, this game has nothing to offer you. Also, there are mods for it now. - 7.4/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
  You'll Enjoy This Game If You Like:   Time/Money/Resource Management   Running a business   Coding alone in your garage   Lots of options/choices that impact each other This is a very solid sim/management game that caters for two different types of players. The first is the casual gamer who just wants to kill a bit of time, develop some games, expand their business and just "see how it goes". But it also caters for those that love analysis and want to squeeze every bit of efficiency out of your approach.Genres, topics, systems and audience chosen for your game, along with other selections based on how long you spend developing certain aspects all play off each other to produce your score/profit. The casual gamer can get by, by responding to the feedback after a game hits the market and more analytical gamers can look into charts and tables that show what is the most effective way to produce a new game.It's lots of fun, is pleasing to the eye and you get to live out your dreams (or nightmares) of becoming an indie dev and possibly even making the big time.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2013
												This game is pure crack! I had no idea such simple game mechanics (basicly using sliders) and micro managment could keep me so interested for such a long period of time.Game Dev Tycoon is solid proof 2 guys in a basement can make better games than some "AAA" titles out there.This game holds some very interesting gaming history (you progress through 35 years. once they're done you finish the game).Wonderful sense of personal growth - you start off as 1 guy in a basement and end up 7 people in a fancy office building.Game Dev Tycoon helps non game developers understand some basic game creation modules, such as game engine and what the hell are contracts, which I found very interesting and informative.Also, this game holds more depth and choice variety than first meets the eye, I'm impressed.Important notes: - The game ends after 35 years (eventhough you can keep playing the same run).- You get to keep your learned knowledge from previous runs in case you decide to start again - Two cons I can think of: 1. Slightly high price (considering the simple game mechanics). This feels more like a $5 title than a $10 title.However I bought it at nearly full price to support the developers and its well worth it.2. Repetetive music - If only they'd get more music variety instead of the same couple of 2 minute tracks on repeat. This is the only game in the world that guilt trips piracy! They get bonus points for that :)TL;DR - Great game, addictive as hell, BUY IT! 9/10.

The Good Stuff++Admit it, if you're a gamer then you've always wanted to be a Game Dev. Now's your chance!+Replay value is great, finished 8-10 games at this point+There's no exact method to make games perfect, it's completely random whether games succeed or fall since there's so many factors to consider+Simple gameplay, not too complicated bu there are other games out there that are more complicated and diverse+Hidden achievementsThe Ok Stuff=Lags as the game progresses, especially if on a lower grade computer/laptop=Workshop support, however almost all mods require a pre-req mod and most affect the flow of the game drasticallyThe Bad Stuff-Some aspects are fixed and pre-determined to where you can't control them regardless (i.e. Some consoles always fail, the popularity of your booth at G3, and others.) The Truthful Hard FactsAcquirement MethodSteam storePrice Paid$9.99Length8-12 hours, replayableThe Elaborate and Perplexing Scoring System10. Overdraw your bank account if needed9. 												This game was an attempt to make a better version of the Kairosofts Mobile game: "Game Dev Story". So far they have not yet succeeded! content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												After having completed the game three times previously with minor obstables, I recently started playing Game Dev Tycoon with pleasent memories in mind. Those memories were brutally shattered after two playthroughs. At a certain point, about seven hours in to the game, reviews change instantaniously from 8.5 and more to 4.5 or less. On two different save files this happened, so I went online and read up on what games to create and great consoll, genre and audience combinations. Regardless the effort, getting back the sales and reviewes that had been given consistently since "the garage" was impossible. The twoes and threes kept coming. Fantasy/RPG, you name it. Bankruptcy on all attempts. So I jumped back on both save files and tried following game creation guides from a point where it all seemed to be going great. The reviews where flying all over the place, 9.75, 9.5, 9, everything was going great again, I could finally get that fuzzy feeling again when Game Dev Tycoon came to mind. But on both occations, with everything researched, the reviews turned sour at the same point as previously. So I do not recommend the game as it now appears. There is no logic in the difficulty patched by the developers of this game. If you crave for a great game dev game, Game Dev Story is much better.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Pick the perfect combination of concept, genre, and platform (while managing marketing, budget, and personnel), and you could have the next gaming sensation on your hands.Game Dev Tycoon is a fun business sim with plenty of inside jokes for anyone who follows the gaming industry. Graphics and sound are quirky (in a good way), the interface in unintrusive and functions rather smoothly, and gameplay is entertaining. My major criticism would be a lack of replay value; after you've successfully completed a 35-year "career," I'm not sure there's much reason to return for a second pass at the game.Nevertheless, that first trip through the game consumes a solid five or six hours of gameplay -- during which I never found myself bored. Overall, Game Dev Tycoon is well worth the price of admission, especially if you can pick it up on sale.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is a very interesting game. You start alone in garage, and end as boss of big company. There's many reaserch option, and making the game isn't always easy. You have to take risk of letting someone overwork to end the game, and you cannot always have everything you want in the game - choose wisely. There is game reports mechanic that allows you to gain insights about released games (like the x topic is great with x genre or like ai is very important for x genre games).There are plenty interesting events that makes a game more interesting, but there isn't many of them. You can make your own consoles from scratch as like a engine. There are many options but i feel like some things aren't balanced good, but maybe only  I've got that feeling. The game is also short. Sometimes you don't know what some options are to. For example, why you can don't have/have online play in MMO? MMO is MMO O_O. The stupid thing is that expansion packs to MMO are made exactly like games. So you can have worse graphic in the same game in DLC. Beside that this game is really fun. If you've seen some videos on Youtube from it and you liked it you should get it. Maybe not for full price, but definitely on promotion. Also there are plenty mods that i haven't tried yet, that will probably make the game better.+: Many reaserch optionsGame development leads you to hard choicesMod supportNice amount of topicsReferences to reality like Govodore G64, Playsystem, Übersoft, Vony, Peter Polyneux :DAbility to make own engine and consoleMake your own game dev studio from scratch-:Small amount of eventsSome bugsNot everything is good balancedStupid expansion pack system to MMO'sNot everything is understandable "All Games" hate me and when everybody give me 10 they give me 9Occasional lagSlightly short7+/10Best of it's kindComand94

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												So you're sitting there in your garage trying to make it big. Video games haven't even developed shading yet, but you're still giving it your all and trying your best. You make a few good games, a few bad ones. You veer dangerously close to the line of poverty and you bite your fingernails in anticipation of the inevitable failure that is sure to consume you. But then..It happens.You make that game. Maybe it's a game about butts evolving into aliens and attacking people. Maybe it's the most sophisticated, most complex idea you've ever mustered up and you may have just crossed the intellectual threshold into ascendance and are on your way towards demigod status. But you do it. You choose that magical Genre/Topic combination, you slide those sliders into juuuust the right spot, and then you watch the reviews.10's. Maybe some 9's. Your jaw drops and your eyes open wide. You look towards the income menu and see hundreds upon thousands of people are buying your game. 100k. 400k. 750k. You hit one million dollars and it just keeps going and then you realize..That was just one game. You're still in a dingy garage. You have to make more. You have to be better. You get a notification that a new office has opened up and is ready just for you and your company. With the most trepidation you've felt since your first day at school, you accept and move on. Taking it all in, you now begin to realize the daunting truth that has now gripped you by the throat. You're hooked. Can't quit now. You have games to make.This is Game Dev Tycoon.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Game Dev tycoon is one of the only games in recent times that has had mee hooked for hours straight, causing me to go without brishing my teeth or getting changed in favour of playing this gem of an indie title rather than catch the bus to the job that I don't have.This game is addictive as f**k. Starting from a guy in a shed in the early 1980s and watching the company of your own name (in my case, NotEACorp) growing into a company releasing games about ninja princesses and getting punched in the balls by critics is wholly satisfying, except for when a critic pans your game, which only makes you want to make a better game to impress him/her/it, thus contributing to the addiction.My only complaint about this game is that, for a game made up of a load of 2D sprites, the randomly appearing framerate drops, while suprising, are more annoying than anything. I understand that indie games aren't the best optimised games on the market, but this is giving me horrifying nighmares about GTA 4 all over again.VERDICT: Go do everything you need to do in your life, gather a stash of food, then buy this game. You'll be glued to your PC until an inevitable powercut comes along to say Hi.10/10. It's not perfect. There's no such thing as a perfect game. But this is as close to perfect as games really come these days.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This was one of the best indie games I've played in a long time, if not ever. If you're a fan of simulation games/tycoon style games, this one will be right up your alley. The game starts basically at the dawn of early gaming starting at the Commodore 64 (renamed G64) and PC, working all the way down history to the Xbox One, PS4 and even simulating new "future" consoles. Your goal is simple: make quality games and lots of money to move out of your garage and eventually start your own game studio. Trying out new genre combinations for games is interesting and deciding where to allocate your resources for best effect (for example, you generally want to go with Fantasy for making an RPG game, Military for Action games etc). Eventually the process gets more and more involved as you have to assign team members to work on games and train their individual strengths deeper. Eventually you can create MMORPGs and "research" projects like a Steam-based platform, and even develop your own console so the game depth only increases as you go along.My only gripes with the game is sometimes critics will be all over the place in regards to their scores. When creating what you thought was an AAA title, they may only end up rating a 7-8, whereas a title you didn't put as much money into, might score 9-10s. Critic score generally dictates how much your game is expected to sell. Also, you move through the eras a bit too quickly, as I completed the game before I was even able to start researching some advanced technologies (like Steam). Though, you could chalk that up to it being my first playthrough.Overall, you're likely to get 6-7 hours out of it your first playthrough assuming you make it to the end without bankruptcy. There isn't a whole lot of replay value but if you're an avid gamer, it's definitely worth it on sale alone for the tongue-in-cheek gaming humor and entertaining gameplay!

content:
Posted: February 23
												Game Dev Tycoon is a fun, simplistic simulation of the interesting game industry and how making games called "Booty Blasters 2: Return of Jaffar" is perfectably acceptable for Young gamers. So is a Typing game with a steering wheel.Positives:-Charming, plain graphics that aren't too hard on the eyes.-Provoking, legitimate strategy when it comes to making a successful game. It isn't just about having correct focuses such as Gameplay or Artifical Intelligence, but also properly using your game's theme in conjunction with the Rating/game console, using specially trained employees to highlight game aspects, research, etc.-The game's difficulty and complexity growth isn't too sudden, most mechanics are pretty easy to understand when they're introduced.-Overall charm and dialogue of the game is fun, it's clear the developers were intentional with their easter-eggs and choices.-Mod support, though modest, is still available and can add to the experience like with many Steam games.Negatives-There are only a couple of soundtracks used, and though they're nice the first time around, it does get a bit tiresome as they loop often.-Replayability is a mixed bag; it's fun to try different strategies and game-styles you didn't try before, but if you know what you're doing, it can become an easy trip until the later years/consoles. Though going for certain achievements can help spice things up a fair bit.-This is a personal note, but I find that the only way to get some of the most interesting parts, such as making an online MMO or your very own console, is to play incredibly optimally or to have the year limit higher than default. More of a nitpick than anything.Overall, I really like Game Dev Tycoon! The price is near perfect for what the game gives you imo, and if you're a fan of tycoons or simple strategy games, this one should be right up your alley. Just make sure to get all the bugs out of your game and you'll be golden!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Yes, I know this is a improved copy of the iOS game, Game Dev Story, I had it and probably spent 100s of hours on a tiny screen. But I'm not reviewing that, I'm reviewing Game Dev Tycoon, by Greenheart studios, not by Kairosoft. Although it's not Game Dev Story, it still is one of the more fun games I have played. You play as a guy/girl who starts their own buisness in their garage, with only 70k (I think :P) and a computed (And maybe a car that's half covered). You must create multiple games until you move up a stage and make a buisness with workers and so on and so forth. Since this game was released, you can now generate a game report, which tells you what you did right, what you did wrong and what you could do to make it better. I know I only have spent a couple of hours, but the game is still amazing and although I've started multiple times, I've never been annoyed with starting over, because I want to see where I went wrong to go bankrupt and how I should change that.The Good: -Addictive gameplay -Fun combinations -Never-ending gameplay-Funny company names (Like, Ninvento or Vonny) The Bad:-Lack of genres - Reviewers suck sometimes Overall score:8/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This game is quite a little gem. For the first game that came out by the Greenheart Games developer, they did spot on. Going through the years and seeing the game industry change from a developer standpoint (all be it their off brand versions. i.e. Vonny = Sony) and even getting to develop your own console at some point is massive fun. It's can be very challenging trying to figure out their interpretation of various genres and play styles, and getting that 10/10 on a game feels very rewarding. They even go so far as to incorporate MMO's, sequels, and expansion packs, all with roughly accurate feelings of how their development and distribution is perceived.Very eager to see if they come out with a sequel, as there are a ton of features I would like to see implemented and current ones that I would love to see expanded. For instance, basic and advanced accounting statistics, expanded skills and point values, and a feedback system for your games, just to name a few.Awesome game, played the hell out of it and would recommend it to anyone who wants a game to just chillax a bit.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Yes, I know this has a metascore of 68, which denotes being "okay" to "pretty good". Yes, I know people have said that this game is a ripoff of a fairly similar mobile phone game. Yes, I know that it's not the perfect game, and that there should have been extra features which could have enhanced it. I too at first thought I'd give it a tentative try, and then suddenly I looked up and saw that it was already evening. If you even have the slightest inclination of liking to manage things, watching numbers, or experiencing success, this game will suck your soul dry and make your eyes bleed videogame fluids. Horrifically, horrifically addictive. It's games like these which justify the existence of rehab centers.

content:
Posted: April 12
												So yeah this game kind of sucked me in. The basic premise is that you start up a software company in your garage in 1980. Back then that was very common, many of the big names started that way. You get a few specific genre's and topics to pick from and differnt graphic modes and such. Then you work on your game. As you go through the game you get new technology such as 3d graphics and branching story lines. As you level up and make money the game opens up more research topics for you to use and new office space. This game doesn't offer a huge amount of options as you play through, however what's here is done very well. I have played through 2 careers doing slightly different things and still find it fun. WIll this be a game you play a year from now? Maybe for the fond memories of it, but it's not really engaging enough to keep you playing it all the time. However, the creators did add a couple of nice messages in the game thanking you for the support and for purchasing their game which I thought was kinda nice,Price vs playability: 7/10Graphics: 7/10 (this is two people who developed the game)Enjoyment: 9/10 for the first couple of play throughsOverall: I am going to give this an 8/10 simply because I did enjoy the game as much as I did. And yeah, I will add more hours to my play time, at least for awhile anyway.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												I've been playing Game Dev Tycoon since way before it was on Steam, since practically the very beginning. Greenheart Games gained a boost of popularity after their little "prank" on game pirates. If you don't know what I'm talking about, I suggest you look it up. Anyways, Game Dev Tycoon is awesome. The replayability is unimaginable. You can constantly talk with your friends about your most recent bestselling game, or you could shut all the curtains, turn off the light, and play until your eyes bleed. The way Greenheart Games made it seem how the in-game world was reacting to your games, it just makes it feel so rewarding. Some people might not even believe that Game Dev Tycoon is their first game. As you can clearly tell, I was suprised too. Great game.10/10. Worth every cent.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I've been playing this game for only a day, and I already want to have its babies. It's the first game in two months that made me stay up late so I could keep playing it. The mechanics are simple and easy to understand, allowing you to get right to the important business of building and customizing your games. And when you finally get that first 10 rating, and that first million bucks, everything has been worth it. Greatly looking forward to sequels/updates/mods/finishing the game.-----This is five weeks and 40 hours of additional gameplay after that first paragraph. I still recommend this game, but with a lot less enthusiasm. The game gets very repetitive after a while, especially because financial success hinges on putting out one near-perfect game every few years or so, with everything else just being filler. I absolutely hope there's a bigger badder sequel in a year or two, one that addresses the following issues:Idiot Publishers: Your mid-game is overly dependent on using publishers so you can make larger games for more money and fans. But more often than not the publisher will either ask for a game you haven't researched, a format you don't have rights to, or a terrible topic/genre combo. I get that it's supposed to make you take chances and expand your options, but if I'm desperate and need a medium game fast, I'd like to actually be able to make one.Employee Stagnation: In order for their skills to improve, your employees must train. Making games gives them nothing; you MUST spend time and research points and capitol on boosting their skills. And you have to do this a lot, which means that you can't be constantly working on games - or researching new topics/engine elements.Chronic Indie Mindset: Even once you hit the late game and become an industry juggernaut, it's still just seven dudes cranking out a game. Yes, you can eventually develop a hardware lab and an R&D department, but they don't directly assist in game-making. I want to become a monster, with dozens - or even hundreds - of employees, making multiple games at once, training some people while others are dedicated to improving my engine and so on.Research Bottleneck: As mentioned above, you need research points to train employees as well as to research new topics and game engine elements. The only way to generate RP for most of the game is to make more games, a newer engine, or generate a game report. As such, you often end up falling behind in either training or engine (or god forbid, both) as you struggle to devote enough points to their multiple needs. I'd recommend being able to create an R&D lab much sooner, thus giving the player many more points to work with, rather than reducing point requirements.Hardware Focused: When I first started playing, I really loved how the game told the history of gaming consoles, as it's not something you hear about a lot when researching gaming history. But consoles are almost exclusively the only outside influence on your game-making. Nothing about software or legal battles or any of that. Just console development. And while interesting, it's such a small part of the story.Forced Conformity: One of this game's mechanics has you matching game topics to genres; the better the match, the better it sells. In other words, you can't make a unique game. For example, according to GDT, Prison/RPG is an okay combination. But what if I want to make a stellar Prison/RPG? Instead of just stating that such-and-such a combination is good or bad, it should be up to the player to make it good or bad. Also, the entire nation of Japan would like to say something about Romance/RPG not being a great combination; I have 60 hours of gameplay and that still messes me up.And yet despite all those flaws, it's still an enjoyable game. In my last playthrough I jokingly made a Vampire RPG called Count of Calypso and it got me out of the basement. The three sequels got me into the final game stage, paid for my R&D lab and new game engine, and became the game I was known for, respectively. I created the Fallout franchise with the help of Dave Johnson, head of Departure Science. Tom Schoffer is somehow a tech genius and became my first AI specialist. I made Half-Life, Half-Life 2, and won the game before I could releas Half-Life 3. There are so many good stories that come out of Game Dev Tycoon; I just wish it were less frustrating to create them.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												This game is extremely fun.  You start out as a 1 man developer in the garage of your mother's house.  As you increase your ability as a developer you increase your stats of technology and design, which allows you to make better games.  As you make better games you make more money, which allows you to upgrade from your garage into offices.  Once you enter the realm of being a professional developer in offices you are able to hire employees and designate their responsibilities from design to technology to research.  All of it works together to allow you to keep upgrading your office, employees, and games.  This game has a way of keeping you hooked.  You get so focused on making sure your next game release is better then your last.  Before you know it, hours have passed and you have work in the morning.  I highly recommend this game.  The price makes this game a no-brainer purchase.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Started a company called Steam, released a console and got pelters until I was out of business !!!! hahahahahaOn a serious note this game is actually quite imersive. The graphics while somewhat simple are actually quite a nice touch. In many respects this is not too disimilar to many other Tycoon based games. There are some really nice touches like how the pcitures of the different cosnoles acrtually look like the ones we all knew and loved (original NES, SNES, Master System ect). Overall the game is quite addicitve, especially once you get into developing and releasing MMO's and expansions. For the price its well worth picking up. It does have its moments, but I think once you have played it thorugh a few times you are probably done. Certainly not a timeless classic, but none the less a decent tycoon / sim game which you should get a few weeks of enjoyment out of. There are some mods you can get from the steam workshop which would probably add a bit more longevity to the overall expereince so well worth going there and checking them out. Only had this a few days, but I do like it. In a nutshell its simply, quirky and fairly addicitive in the short term.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												An simple tycoon game where you own your own game development company. You start off in a garage and work your way up to an office and employees. It's obvious that the creators of this game has knowledge about the gaming industry, both when it comes to gaming history and game development. There is a steady storyline (although not the most intriguing) throughout the game, where you, your company and employees evolve aswell as the gaming industry. I have never come across a tycoon game with this theme before so I was glad to find that the tutorial was short and easy to understand. Also the tutorial is only mandatory upon your first game.When creating a game "you" have no knowledge about what subjects, theme and platform works together, but as you develop games, the game register the outcomes which helps you make better games. Personally I think this function isn't ultimate and would prefer a full register (for example a grid) where you clearly can see what works and what does not, instead of having to click everything and see if the game tells you it's a good combo.Overall this is a great game. Even though the story doesn't change, I keep playing! I would like to see the creators make a sequel or an upgraded version because despite my criticism, there isn't really anything wrong with the game, there's only a lot of room for improvement. Considering this is their first game, that's impressive!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												This game is more of a history lesson through the years, rather than an actual game development simulator. Many of the combinations in the game are obvious, and the only real excitement you get is when you create a game that gets "10" reviews across the board from every "reviewer". These reviewers tend to be little ♥♥♥♥♥es, and before you ever create a perfect game, one of these little ♥♥♥♥♥es will give you a 9. You'll probably cry for a couple of hours like I did, but then you'll feel a little better and MAYBE replay it if you're feeling like you should be beat in the face a little more.I mean, the game has good replayability value when it comes to perfecting your algorythm and getting that perfect game, but it's tough to enjoy the game at face value when everything tends to not only be the same, but also ridiculously predictable, whether it be console releases, or which console will be on top in the "war" (SNES>genesis, RIP dreamcast gone too soon, and N64>PS1). There isn't a whole lot to discover in this game after you get three or so good combinations. It was too easy for me to continuously switch between sequels for my RPG "ELDERLY WRITTEN PASSAGES" and my shooter "Shut up mom, I'm in the middle of a match" and consistently get high ratings and drown in it (the cash, that is).Overall, it's a fun experience the first time, especially if you don't remember the early console wars, but after that, the fun dwindles down. I give this one three little ♥♥♥♥♥ reviewers, and one midget ♥♥♥♥♥ reviewer out of five

Posted: June 18, 2016
												Without a doubt this has become one of my go to games when i feel like playing casually, it's simple and easy to understand and can be a little addicting. I often find myself playing it for several hours without realizing it, or sometimes for just half an hour, and that's what makes this game so good. It's just so easy to pick up and play,  and it can take a very long time to master or even simply complete the game. I often found my self ecstatic whenever i made a perfect 10/10 game, and  what makes it so special is the reward you get for creating a master piece, keeping you exited and happy. It just makes you want to keep on playing, keep on succeding, trying to hit that perfect mark again. In all honesty this is a well polished game that is incredibly fun to play, and i would recommend it to any one who is looking for something new or just something fun and rewarding. It is very fearly priced that deserves your attention, so try it out because i doubt you'll be disopointed.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												As an Indie game, this is not bad. I'm a fan of the original Tycoon games, so it's safe for me to say that this Indie game made it pretty far. If you think about it, it's not about the graphics or music - it's about the strategy and the satisfaction you get from that successful achievement of being, well, successful. This is one feeling we all have deep down inside and it can come from anywhere, real life scenarios, or video games. Rather you're fishing and finally got a hook, or moving to the next stage in this game it's the same feeling of accomplishment. The only thing the game lacks is maybe a higher time frame between console releases. It seems to be a little too fast-paced when you're actually sitting here playing it. This game could also use a meter on how fast you'd like time to pass rather it's real-time or 100x faster for example.Pros:-Addictive gameplay-Allows your creativity to fly-Good engine-Basic controls (Rather you're a gaming veteran or a newcomer, anyone can play with ease)Cons:-No control on the time flow -You'll mostly always feel rushed-Could use some more tweakingOverall, I'd give this a 8/10. I can tell this took some time to actually develop - as I said before it's not about the graphics or music that made this the game it is today, it's the gameplay. From what I can tell, it took awhile to actually make this game fully functional which needs to be credited. This could be a text-based game and I'd still enjoy it.Would I recommend it? Maybe, I wouldn't say $10 USD would be worth Game Dev Tycoon, however I'd say around the $4.99 or lower range (on sale) would be reasonable. Some have regrets about buying this game, you need to give it time or maybe start over. The point is, have fun.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Game Dev Tycoon is exactly what you expect: a videogame developer tycoon. You are supposedly warped back in time to 1985 to a reference-filled (hint: flux capacitor) garage, where you begin your endeavour into the gaming history books. Like any developer who travels in time to 1985, you are absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥at programming because the technology is so different.  You have a computer that's literally worse than a modern graphing calculator, yet you decide to make games. If you are successful, you can grow your garage into an actual company, with actual people, and actual results. You have to strategically market your games for specific audiences (you know, like "T for Teen" or "E for Everyone") and try to match genres to different gaming platforms to different audiences.For example, kids. In the real world, devices like the Nintendo DS (which reminds me, tell you later) or the great old Gameboy are very popular. Add a role-playing/ adventure game like the Legend of Zelda, and you're all set. Target marketing at young people, and kaboom: ez skins, ez life. Although "skins" probably means nothing to the world of the 1980s and 90s.So, now, about the NDS. The developers, in an effort to give you a good laugh, and avoid copyright infringement, have sort of parodied every console on the market. If I'm correct, the Nintendo GameCube's counterpart is the GameSphere. It's actually kinda freaking amazing.I'll give GDT a solid 8, maybe an 8.5 because of the extensive workshop mod support.TL;DR: Time travel to 1985, make games, ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥es, get money. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												A forgettably bland spreadsheet simulator. While many games can be reduced to the math to some extent, the art of hiding this, or simply increasing the complexity to the point where optimization is no longer feasible due to multiple constraints and varying situations, is crucial.Game Dev Tycoon has nothing to do with making games. It is solely concerned with making the player drag around a set of sliders to find the optimal combinations, in the pursuit of ever larger numbers. The window-dressing of a game development studio is immaterial, as it impacts precisely nothing.This is not to say that it is a bad spreadsheet, in and of itself. The game is perfectly functional, and the puzzle of searching for ideal combinations might satisfy an evening, or more for the kind of person that enjoys the optimization challenge. However anyone who does not find such appealing would be well advised to find something else to do with their time.

												Not a fan of the genre, just a guy who was interested about the theme of the game. And, from the theme perspective, it's very flavorful. But when you figure out how to "game" the system, how to manipulate the numbers correctly, then it becomes a simple spreadsheet, that's nothing more than chosing the correct options every time. There isn't enough factors to challenge the player to think, to actually do the logical things that are true in normal game design. It's all way too set in stone, and it's way too easy to figure out the way to play the game, then it loses all the appeal for me.

												The combination of the topic 'Game Industry' with the genre 'Simulation-Tycoon' is definitively great and addictive.After a few tutorials there is a "thank you for your purchase" message poping up early in the game, which make it more casual even :) In overall, the game offers an easy  Gameplay with comprehensive missions panel in which the focus will be set on finding the best combination of parameters to get the AAA game, the item that will bring you fame and money. Starting in your humble garage, you are given '35 equivalent-years' to become the Steve-Bill-Dave of the Virtual Game Development.So, get famous or go bankrupt while trying :)However, the game is - IMHO - not at its peak yet. Besides the few Story Events that help to break the monotony of the game, many progresses can be done in order to make it more challenging and even fancier.Among other stuffs that would benefits of an improvement: # Exp gained display after production is too slow and too long  # Specialized Press Reviews after game publishing is slow, fancy-less and repetitive # Training and Updgrade trees are difficult to read and exploit: a more comprehensive tree-chart would help to understand how the items benefit to what. # full tracking of game reports and specifiations is not in history, therefore difficult to develop the right 'sequel', alternative, or spin-off # Marketing and SEO elements not enough developped: effect of campaigns and events should be more visible # Lack of customization in the officeWhile I purchased the game during Mid-Week Madness, I think the bargain is fair. And I truly believe this game is setting a first stage of expectation that needs to be materialized in a sequel I surely be looking forward. !!Keep up the good work.___________ionah

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												The story of the game is that you go back to the year 1985 and start your own game company. You start off in a garage which you can upgrade to a technical suite and more! As time progresses there are news popups which describe events that are taking place in the gaming industry at the time. For example: Vonny has just released their second video game system. Some games you make may be a smash hit but others not so great, you must be wise with the topic, genre and console. You can earn millions or become bankrupt. To improve the chance of making a great game is to hire staff which becomes available in the upgraded garage (becomes the technical suite). The staff can be used to help make games, research topics and research different features of the engine. When you start off, the game may be a bit tricky but once you learn which topic matches with which genre it will seem easier. With the ability to make games there is a cost. At the start of each career you recieve a certain budget which you can use to develop your first game! It randomly selects the first topics you can use so don't excpect to get the one you want. During making games with the budget you can go bankrupt, although it seems bad you can get two chances before you finally go bankrupt and have to start over.Overall Rating: 9/10 (Highly Recommended)I rate this game a 9 out of 10 because of how addicting it is, the details of the game and the dream of any gamer to make their own game company. Green Heart Games need to make a few tweaks which are only little ones. For example when the reviews of the games you make pop up it takes 20 seconds to display all of them. I feel that this wastes time but you can download a mod off of the workshop to reduce it to 1 second but hopefully they will change it anyway :).Thanks for reading this review and good luck with your game company :)Daniel

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												In Game Dev Tycoon, there are a wide range of games you could release on a variety of consoles throughout the years. You start right when gaming takes off or so, with two options to develop for, as time passes on you get more options. Those options are twists on the real names of consoles that have gone through over time, as well as the companies who developed them. A big part of the game is research. What is research exactly? You get research from doing various things such as completing contract work, which gives you money for completion, but takes your money if you don't complete it in time. You can also get it from other things like making games. What is research used for? Upgrades to your games to make them even better and bring in those big scores. Big scores means big money to make more big games. It turns into an endless cycle, until you're a billionaire. Your games can have different topics which you have to research, and can be in a variety of genres. It's up to you to decide what genre and topic works best, and where you should divert your resources during development. You can also hype up your game by putting out ads, or going to the game's equivalent of E3 and setting up a booth. Hyping up a bad game is bad for your company, but hyping up a really good game will reward you greatly. In the second stage of the game you can start to hire staff. They're really useful but aren't that great at first. Remember to train them up, but don't forget to work on your own character as well.Game Dev Tycoon also has a modding community, although some of the mods don't work very well. You can still find plenty of good mods that add content and expand the game though. I didn't get mods myself until after my first or second playthrough though.Some bugs and annoyances I've found are that late game, with too many bubbles your game can lag, although a mod can fix that on the workshop. Also I've recently run into some issues with tabbing out and changing the size of the screen. I haven't run into any game breaking bugs, but watch out if you plan on modding because some of them can conflict, and break the game.I'll give this game a 6.75/10. I enjoyed it a lot but I feel that it does have some issues. I still recommend it, though.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a wonderful game for what it represents. The plot is fantastic and I love how it uses true events with slightly renamed consoles and games, far better than if they made up all the consoles and games. The game gives you a lot of choice, is very simple to understand and with so many different possibilities and outcomes, the game has yet to become stale for me so far.However, in my hour so far of playing, I am already finding it very hard to make perfect games. Whilst game reports are a very good way to get information about good and bad combos, the reviews are lacking in depth with some simply saying things like 'Enjoyed it' and 'Good'. If the reviewers went into more depth like they sometimes do when mentioning things like 'medieval works really well with strategy' then I'd much prefer the reviews and actually find them useful, however, as it stands, the best way to get information on your game is to file a game report. Whilst I have not played this game for too long, my first impressions are for the most part very positive. The game is very simple to play and is perfect for some relaxing late-night gaming. The game adds enough challenge with its numerous choices and certainly does require a lot of thought into some decisions in order to maintain enough money to save yourself from going bankrupt, however isn't impossibly difficult to grasp. Overall, my opinion on 'Game Dev Tycoon' is very positive, however I do feel the lack of in-depth reviews really does hinder its potential. But this is one con among many pros and should certainly not put you off playing this wonderfully unique experience.Rating: 3/4

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Ah, Game Dev Tycoon. I find this game fantastic, for one core reason. It's brilliant wishfulness which lets players build and grow a gaming company. You will hire employees, purchase buildings, develop games, build consoles and anything else you can imagine. This is where the game shines, it allows people to an extent express how they think a game company should be ran.However while most gamers will enjoy this game to some degree, if you don't find the idea of running your own company appealing, you'll likely find the game fairly boring since the gameplay is fairly basic. With it completely based upon moving sliders which represent how you and your employees focus effort on how you build your games.Pros:Thematic Endless Wishfulness for gamersSteam workshop helps the longevity of playCons:Gameplay is fairly simple and can get fairly boringGame is fairly unclear on how to make quality gamesWon't get much out if it, if you don't care for the consent of running your own game company.Linux port report: I found the Linux version of this game to be adequate, it still runs smoother on windows, but it's a good effort none the less. The only problems I found was a little bit of additional delay when selecting menus and an occasional font sizing problem. However, despite this, it is perfectly playable on Linux.Overall it's a Solid Recommendation

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Oh man, where do I begin. Game Dev Tycoon is one of the best simulation games I've ever played. It gives you a general feel of how the game industry has evolved throughout the years, parodying famous events, and has really immersive gameplay combined with that "one more turn" feel from titles like Civilization V. I'd recommend it to anybody who likes, well, having fun.Game Dev Tycoon sets you off in your own measly garage, making a 2D game. But as you make more and more games, you witness the world around you change: gaming becomes more popular, companies arise, and it becomes the next trend. The game portrays this transformation amazingly: you get to experience firsthand how the gaming industry morphed small developers into the giants of gaming today. Along this path, you manage your own gaming company, churning out titles that decide your company's fate, and, the gaming world's fate.The gameplay in Game Dev is deceptively simple. You create games, with certain genres, and you allocate how much time each specific part needs (such as Level Design, or Engine). Over time, you learn what combinations create your AAA games, and what can give you the most money. Along the way, you add more features: Character Progression, Loading Screens, etc. Eventually, you'll be able to make giant projects, and more! Throughout this entire time, you also manage your staff, control marketing, and PR. It gives a very immersive experience in the simulation genre.Furthermore, the game provides lots of replayability. Every new game start provides different scenarios, and you can tell the game to veer off course of what happened in reality. The Steam Workshop community provides even more: hundreds of mods for the game can change your experience, whether it be the addition of "Next-Gen Consoles", or the pcmasterrace. The game goes way beyond the initial purchase, giving you endless opportunities.Game Dev Tycoon may not be a AAA title, but it's definitely worth its price, and more. It features very immersive gameplay and storytelling, a fabulous community, and an overall well-designed game. Kudos to Greenheart Games for making one of my favourite simulation games of all time!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												It's a trial-and-error-based strategy game, and once you start to figure out each of the five genres, the game is pretty easy. Even with multi-genre mixups it's pretty self-explanatory on how to allocate your time during development. Past this thin surface level of gameplay, there really isn't enough depth to keep you going.A lot of seemingly obvious features are missing from the development process, probably to keep the game simpler and more accessible, but I feel like a lot of replayability is lost in their absence. For every step in the development process of a game, I found myself wanting more concise control, but this is by no means a game of micro-management. You market your game by pressing "market" and have little to no input on HOW your game is marketed, for example. The success of your game winds up relying on when you release your game, and how you allocated your time. It's so bare-bones and minimal that the sense of achievement wears off quickly and you begin to feel like you're not working for your success. That being said, I still played for about 10-12 hours before it was effortles and mundane, so I think I still got my moneys worth. If you're looking for a simple game to relax to where you don't have to do much aside from click through menu's, it's a great choice, and that's really all I wanted.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Do I develop a text based adventure or try to make a sim game? Ok text based adventure just to get my foot in the ground.  Oh no, what system? Can I afford a licensing fee? Is there enough market share to make it worth my time? Did I even focus on the correct attributes!? Are adventures even popular at the moment? Ok ok let's release the game, if it fails I'll be bankrupt and that will be the end of me. 7, 6, 6, 8Ok not too bad! I'll live to make a new game! Well do I make a new game or upgrade my game engine!? Should I hire new staff or train existing staff? What to do what to do?These questions and more will be up to you and your new game company. If your itching for a tycoon experience this should be right up your ally. Make games, earn money, hire staff, fire staff, change offices, create game engines, even make your own console. All of these things and more are awaiting for you in this lovely gem of a game. You may even learn a thing or two of the history of consoles, even if they are using fake names. I picked this up during the 2013 Holliday sale and wasn't expecting much, but what I got was a "just one more game I need good reviews!" Kind of addiction. I didn't put it down till I got every achievement! If you were a fan of Zoo Tycoon or Roller Coaster Tycoon like I am you should give this game a shot. This game doesn't disappoint! I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a wonderful game for what it represents. The plot is fantastic and I love how it uses true events with slightly renamed consoles and games, far better than if they made up all the consoles and games. The game gives you a lot of choice, is very simple to understand and with so many different possibilities and outcomes, the game has yet to become stale for me so far.However, in my hour so far of playing, I am already finding it very hard to make perfect games. Whilst game reports are a very good way to get information about good and bad combos, the reviews are lacking in depth with some simply saying things like 'Enjoyed it' and 'Good'. If the reviewers went into more depth like they sometimes do when mentioning things like 'medieval works really well with strategy' then I'd much prefer the reviews and actually find them useful, however, as it stands, the best way to get information on your game is to file a game report. Whilst I have not played this game for too long, my first impressions are for the most part very positive. The game is very simple to play and is perfect for some relaxing late-night gaming. The game adds enough challenge with its numerous choices and certainly does require a lot of thought into some decisions in order to maintain enough money to save yourself from going bankrupt, however isn't impossibly difficult to grasp. Overall, my opinion on 'Game Dev Tycoon' is very positive, however I do feel the lack of in-depth reviews really does hinder its potential. But this is one con among many pros and should certainly not put you off playing this wonderfully unique experience.Rating: 3/4
