Posted: December 22, 2013
												GREAT GAME. Game Dev Tycoon is probably the best indie game that has come out this year. If you have any interest in tycoon/business games even if you have no experience with them, this game is perfect for you. The game gradually builds up so learn as the game progesses but it never gives you the overwhelming feeling from being too complex. The game actually follows the history of video game consoles pretty well, even going as far as making realistic predictions of what the next generation of consoles will be (After the Xbox ONE and PS4). So those also interested in video games (which if you're on steam then you probably are) will enjoy the history lesson that's incorporated perfectly into the game.You really must try this game out and it is definitely worth the $10, and if you manage to get it while it's on sale then it's a steal. Try the game out you will love it and spend countless hours building your game dev empire.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												This is one of the most fun, addictive, and entertaining games I've played in a while. It's your basic resource management sim (similar to something like SimCity or Roller-coaster Tycoon) yet focused on the gaming industry. I can honestly say I've developed a fake game with all the care and time that many of our beloved indie game developers have done only to see it sell a small amount and lose me money; in contrast, I've poured fortunes into a casual handheld game about puppies just to make exponential profit and secure the jobs of my employees. Posted: April 19, 2014
												Ever thought you knew everything about games the funding the hard work and telling other what to focus on is the name of the game. You start out solo as a freelancer and thus cant make your AAA games early on you need to recruit others howver you cant do that in the tutorial (since you are ecantially making games ain your basement to start) you do eventually upgrade to skyscaper and get to make the games you dreamed of (well since its a simulation game like sim city its not like you need to do everything yourself)Ok hows the gameplay? Well first you get 4 random topics (like horror, mystery, etc) then you pick a genre then you have to go though the enire process of making the game from beginning to end its automatic however you have to distrube your funds and effort to different things in order for your game to work. For example RPG dont need high quality music you need to focus on gameplay and story nearly 100%, however a dancing game its a very bad idea to ignore music you are asking for the game to take your money. you must spend research points to unlock more (which is rencondmended)The object of the game like I said above build an empire starting in the 80s (yes the 80s and see the entire gaming intrustry evolve around you) in 1992 the snes comes out, in 1996 the n64 comes out by then are you good enough to make games for that system?  Its not easy you lose money every week but you can gain massive money back if you get a blockbuster. Its a good idea to memorize what happened in real life will you invest in the sega cd or the dreamcast uh....The sad part is every event happens in the same order on every playthough but you can try to make different games to see how it goes one game you can try lots of RPGs another go for more Action games its all up to you.The game uses a rating system remember gamespot and ign? well they are all in game yes with pardoyed names but every time you make a game and delete all the bugs (its a bad idea not too) they rate you depending on where you put the focus on the most. Also they take into effect the system you publisjhed on (they are graphic you know if you dont keep up with the times they will destroy you with their rating of 1-3/10 ouch >_>) Trying to please the pro gamers is very hard and part of the fun getting a perfect score is challenging and there are so many factors that can lower your score. Overall it makes the game much better too..Ok some game hints since this is a very hard game and you probably wont make it to the end on a 1st playthough. First you need to figure out what kinda game you want to make (dont do same the types of genre in a row however do keep focusing on that since you can level up in that style <for example doing lots of RPG skyrockets your story, world building, and dialogue exp bar a lot while doing lots of Action skyrocket your graphics, gameplay, and level design exp bars>) remember once you unlock sequel this is a huge opurtunity to do it since if its a sequel to a 10/10 you did earlier but with better graphics/sound/ and features the reviewers are going to love it and you gain lots of hype since the gamers know that you are making a game to a game they loved in the past.Also another mistake beginners make is recruiting way too good employees dont go for the best of the employee you do pay them all by the month (in addion to rent costs) starting with low skilled employees and then training then over time allows the costs to remain reasonable and overall make sense in real life (no newbie company hires top tier employees they cant afford them but the employees that stay with the company for a long time gets better and can even surpass the so called great employees that demand crazy monthy prices.Also another mistake beginners make is not make games for publishers until they get a fanbase (usually around 100k fans is a good number to start making your own games without help) when you are making games for other companies like Nintendo, tecmo, and many others. You only get a % of the money but your fans skyrocket really its much better in the long run so ya...once you move out of the basement its best to work for others for a while to get the fans to know you.since the quality of the games is on your employee skill levels you should train them until they are in the 500's in design,tech, and reseasch.  With stats that high they can specialze which allows you to make even better games. Once you get 6 employees spend the time to get employees with over 700 in either tech or design (this is the only time you should hire top tier employees if you need a specialist asap and you can afford his outragous monthy price) and pay to make him a specilist (which is 200 research points and a million dollars and 3-6 weeks training) they will pay off in the long run once someone has 700 design (or you hire him) and you pay for the training you unlock the design area where the final two graphic upgrades and otehr amazing upgrades are. a 700 tech that you pay the price upgrading him can unlock the area where you can make your own gaming system which will be much better then even the playstation 5, xbox1, and wii u yes you will dominate everything once you make your own gaming console.  Some speicists require 725 tech or design <_< though.Remember the main character (you) has amazing stats 300 in everything and 0 monthy costs. Never gets tired ever. But he still can get confused (stops the bar while you scratch your head its random) Train him well hes the best character in the whole game by the end its not uncommon to have him with 600 in everything (even speed which is the most useless stat) while remaining free and has infinite stamina (no need to go on a vacation). And the best part he can specilize :D totally worth it to do that too.Ok the another hint I'll give is marketing it is really useless in the beginning (since you dont have many fans) however once you start making bigger games (esp the AAA games) you need to market or else no one will know you are working on the game and thus all your hard work and effort will be unknown. Yes marketing is great and all however the big opportuny to gain media attention is the G4 (A parody) You can choose a small,medium, or large booth once a year and this generates so much hype. Once you are a multi millionare and is making a huge game with lots of features picking the big booth will skyrocket your hype and make tons of fans to buy the game day one rather then wait. Yes you will get the money you spent on marketing back if you do a good job.Last hint If you get a 10/10 game and you see the words the other publishers are giving jealous looks the pro gamers from then on will lower your overall score. Yes they are comparing all your future games to that masterpiece it can ruin the rest of your game. A good tip is dont go for your magnum opus too early or else the reviewers will expect too much from you and kill your score on the next game. Since the game lasts 35 years on an avg playthough go for the best of the best nearing the end.The biggest component is your graphics always keep that up to date and make new engines to run them (you need a design specialist with 700 design points and pay the requirement for the upgrade) to get the final two upgrades for graphics with the final one being holographic technology which is really cool. Overall its a great game little short but at only $10 you get to expierence the gaming world from a game maker pov from the 1980 all the way to 2015 (yes the future) once it reaches that the games over your high score is tallyed and the game ends...on a first play though getting straght 10/10 ratings from all the pro reviewers is really a pain in the neck but its so rewarding once you finally see the 11/10 and the AAA badge for making a masterpiece game. OR if you're adventerious try to make an MMO without getting a game over that is very hard to pull off...

												Game Dev is a CASUAL game. This is a four letter word to me. Had i noticed that it was a CASUAL game, i would never have given it a chance. The amount of gamer lore and trivia in here is phenominal! From old editors of magazines to the true timeline of video game consoles, this game is packed with stuff that only a gamer from the 80s or before would get. Srsly the lore is nuts, srsly. ^_^ Great game Greenheart! Greenheart, Please feel free to use all that steam cash and make more games with the same attention as you did this little timesink, oh and thanks for making me see that 'Casual' does not mean boring/dumb/many four letter words!TL;DR = Great under 5$ game.

												I had $150 Million dollars cash in my bank. So, I decided to make an awesome AAA game...I used the "Unreal Engine, Mach 4" which itself cost around $100M to create. Then, I sunk 7M into R&D, creating an awesome Action/Adventure MMO with a Horror setting.All was going well. I had my $2M Marketing package timed with G3, in which I plopped down $1.5M for a huge booth. "SLAM" reporting asked me if I thought the game should be hyped or not, and I went ALL IN on the hype machine.Game had 669 Hype Rating.Then... the reviews came in: "Uninspired", "Dull", "Pretty Bad" all across the board.I was about to throw my keyboard through my iMac's monitor when I realized that I had made the most obvious error possible...I had named the game, "Walking Dead". Yep, Sounds about right.(Epilogue - Thankfully, I still had $25M left. I made "The Sims" a casual/simulation of "Life",  on a shoestring budget -with help from the bank-  and raked in about $90M. All is well)

Posted: January 6, 2015
												Tagging Game Dev Tycoon with the labels 'Simulation', 'Indie' and 'Management' may be accurate.  After all, it is a simulation of managing a game development studio (and a surprisingly engaging one).  But, in reality, these tags don't fully do the game justice.  Like great strategy games, it places a premium on decision making without being punishingly constricting.  It has a vein of self-determination that good RPGs possess (i.e. want to become a megalithic AAA pumping machine, or see how far you can go working alone in your garage?).  It allows for flexible resource management like a good business sim should.  But, most importantly,  this is a game that possesses that just-one-more-turn factor that any good game of its ilk needs.  In this case a turn is really a development cycle, but why quibble?If someone isn't a particular fan of job/business simulators this game still has enough going for it that they're likley to find something to enjoy about it.  At full price the game definitely delivers value for money for fans of the genre.  For others, give it a shot when it's on sale and you likely won't regret it.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												preface:  In this review, keep in mind that I am following release dates to the US-only releases of products. I am not going to include EU or JP release dates due to this games setting being in the US. With that out of the way, let's get on with the review.-Game Dev Tycoon is a indipendence medium-game developed by Greenheart Games. And let me tell you: It's fun and addictive.Game Dev Tycoon is about ''You'' being a video/PC-Game devloper in the post-1983 crash/Atari Shock and working your way up top all the way up to the year ...2018? I think.-[Let's talk about the story]The story isn't mush to talk about.It begins with the post-'83 crash were computer-games survived the disaster, Nintendo reviving  consoles in late-1985, Sega releasing GENESIS in 1989, SONY releases PS1 in late-1995 and so on.The story is abridged though, so some events have been cut-out... such as Apple in the 80/90s, Linux, SEGA Saturn, all the add-ons for the GENESIS and *Panasonics 3DO*Though the 3DO didn't do well in US and EU and is nothing in comparison to GENESIS and SNES, it deserves recognition in gaming history for selling well in Japan.-[Let's talk about the gameplay]When developing a game, you are presented with three development stages and three pillars for each development stage(total of nine pillars).You adjust the pillars  to what works and what doesn't work. Whether you want to focus a lot on gameplay or focus a little on A.I. or don't focus on the story etc.After all the three development stages are done, you then wait for reviews.If you get very bad reviews, then that's going to give you negative fans and make less money depending on the reviews and if you hyped the game before release.If you get great reviews, then you are going to make a lot of money and have a huge following. journalists and critics will mention your great feat and with recognition you will get offers from different people.Game dev Tycoon has a... sort of.. roguelike feel to it. If you mess up in the beginning and make a wrong decision then you could get a game-over.If you make 1M dollars, you then move to an office and hire more staff and make bigger games.Though I think this is a great gameplay mechanic, I still think there are a couple of ''missed opportunities'' in the gameplay that could have been in the game. Such as:-You can't make a launch title. Or/and getting an offer from SONY or Nintendo for an exclusive title.-You can't put a price on a game. -Why can't you make something viral? like spreading a rumour of a hidden room or a mythical creature or something, like GTA with big foot. Or Mortal Kombat with the blood code on SNES.-Why can't you make 2 games at the same time. one small game an a large game for example.-Why can't you make an expansion pack on a normal game? You can make an Exp. pack, but only on MMOs.-Why can't my character have a background? not all companies starter out as one guy like Bungie. Some starter out as three guys such as Blizzard....and so on. I have a mush bigger list in my head of ''missed opportunities'' with GDT. These are a few example.-[Let's talk about the Graphics]Game Dev Tycoons graphics is hand drawn animation. I like Game Dev. Tycoons graphics.-[Let's talk about the music]For a simulator that's all about developing games, the music in this game isn't really that important. Game Dev Tycoons music is relaxing and kind to your ears.-[Before I give my ''Final Score'', I would like to say something]GDT opened up my point of view of how it looks like when developing a game. Before I played GDT I thought ''Ok... developers keep saying in interviews that the reason they can't make a sequel is because it's NOT that easy'' and I am all like ''well... maybe they're just saying that because they just want to make money and don't really care about the fans''. And after I played GDT, I finally understood what developers were saying about ''It's NOT that easy''.-[Final Score]GDT is a great game... but I feel like there were a lot of missed oppertunities. But it can be forgiven because of the addicive gameplay and for being an indie-game. I didn't like that the story was abridged and your main-character was ''another avarage Joe''. That's why I give GDT a ''great'' 8.5/10 and a ''recommended'' for anybody.I can reccommend game dev. Tycoon to anybody, even casuals. Even If you're not familiar with Simulations. And also, if you have the motivation to learn and such, then GDT is for you.[Here is an idea I have for ''Greenheart Games'' if they ever make a sequel]If Greenheart Games ever make a sequel to GDT or an Exp. Pack. Then I am would like them to add those ''missed opportunities'' that I talked about in the ''gameplay''-section.I would also like the sequel/exp. pack to follow the gaming history more accurately.-...And that's my review of GDT. Peace out and have a good one.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is a fun and even nostalgic game for mature gamers out there. Players are tasked with starting a game development company and controlling the development and release of games as the years pass. New technology is introduced as time passes, which can play a role in how you wish to develop your games and company. The game is scripted to have release events of real consoles (named slightly differently for copyright reasons I am guessing). The release of these consoles is actually quite comical- you'd just have to play to see what I mean.Games can be named, sequels can be made to games. Research can be done to unlock tech, employees can be selected and hired and trained and their roles can be specialized so that areas such as "World Design" or "Artificial Intelligence" can be professionally implemented in your games. You can control which employee works on which part of the game and how much time they have to spend.. different types of games will favor you spending more time in different areas. For example, RPG games will require you to allot more time in World Design and Story/Quests. Overall, the design mechanics are a bit repetitive, but if you wish to have a lot of variety you can choose to develop different kinds of games. I was continually pleasantly surprised at how much detail was in the game and how much you could actually control and do. You can eventually create your own console, MMO's and even expansion packs. The economy of the game is forgiving enough for new players, but in order to succeed to a high degree you would need to think carefully about what you are doing.The first night I played, I played almost all night and managed to basically finish the main story line. That being said, I felt like there was a choice of pathways. I could go back to this game and not feel as though it was the exact same experience. Is there unlimited replayability? The short answer is no, but if you have a good imaginination, you could have fun almost every time you decide to play.

Posted: August 13, 2014
												This is actually something of a pleasant surprise.  I wasn't expecting much going in, but it had a fun idea and it was on sale so I gave it a shot and have ended up loving it.  It has just the right balance where it's pretty easy to learn, difficult to master and despite a simple and user friendly interface and design it can get challenging and has a relatively fast pace and in game clock and while I will admit I think it maybe moves too fast  in that regard as even the most successful of your games won't stay on the market much longer than a minute and a quarter.  Still, there's a flow to the game and its worth toying with and has a nice depth and I do like the fact that it gives you more control over the actual services the company you run provides, in fact the game actually eschews the model of designing your building and micromanaging dozens of employees almost entirely in favour of static levels (Though you still have win conditions based on how much moolah you have and how effecient your workers are) and instead puts the meat of the game into having a direct influence on your studios games from naming them, creating custom engines for them, selecting their marketing, choosing who develops what aspect of a game (At least when you get to medium game projects) and researching new development aspects and parts for your next in-house Engine.  Admittedly I'm pretty bad, I have finally gotten to a point where I can usually make it up to the release of the "DreamVast" and "PlaySystem 2" but almost always lose all my capital right around the time the "mBox" shows up.  I honestly don't fully know why, it seems I could take a winning formula and give it over 120 points in both areas, set a record, and then still get scores of 1 and 3 and then watch as my fans and my money get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥away.  Oh well, it's still a lot of fun and that's the point, ain't it?  If you like these kinds of games give it a shot!

Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game is something else. I'm not a gamer who really enjoys "Tycoon" style games, The Sims/Sim City, or anything of that ilk. I bought this game because it was on sale, I love games and the idea of making them and it had a lot of people surprised. So I started it up not sure what to expect and I fell in love with it.It's what I'd call Simulation lite in that it's not super in depth with the customization choices, but it is enough so to make it fun and interesting. You basically follow the exact path of the game industry from the C64 on. You start out only being able to dev simple text based rpgs or 2d Space Sims, but quickly enter the "Console Generation" as Nintendo and Sega enter the scene. You'll have to pay licensing costs, but you'll need to in order to make your company a success and get out of the dying C64 market. You need to maintain a steady streak of sales in order to support your next break away hit so that hopefully it won't just be you in your garage anymore. I started out just wanting to see what it was all about, but I got sucked in. I went from, "I'll just make one game and see what it's all about..." to "Just one more..." to "Okay. What will my sixth game be about? I need cash!" It is one of the simplest games you'll play, but done in such a way that you can't help be enjoy the hell out of it.I'm a gamer who plays just about anything, but I focus on RPGs, FPS, Action/Adventure, etc. Even though I don't generally enjoy simulation games, this one is so playable and enjoyable, I don't think it really matters what style of games you enjoy most. It has something for just about everyone.And to the Devs: You are very welcome for the support! =D You people have a bright future if you keep making engrossing little titles like this. Can't wait to see what you do next.

Posted: September 22, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon: think you can build the best games?It starts off slow: you're in a garage, with only so many topics open. You churn out game after game to earn your living.Then you get your first big hit. You hire an employee or two. You start to experiment more. And when you realize you're just one number off from the perfect hit, you start to analyze, tweak your formula a little and go "just one more game".Admittedly, it's not for everyone. You're going to spend a lot of time watching bubbles, watching charts and watching numbers spin. You'll probably grind for a while, just trying to keep the money flowing. But if you enjoy a strategy game that slowly gets more complicated and clever and makes you wonder how to do just a *little* bit better, here we go.

Posted: January 17, 2015
												Just finished my first playthrough and wow, what a great game! Had me totally hooked, couldn't stop playing.Pros:The mechanics are deep, but not complex to the point where it becomes a riddle. You will gradually get the gist of every genre, which does make the game easier, but the addition of different expansions and resources does shake up things a bit.  It gives you a nice sense of progression as you make more and more hit games.Cons (more like things I'd like to see in a sequel):Some things bothered me during my playthrough, mainly the way it deals with sequels. If you make a sequel of a hit game without doing something else first the game punishes you. There is no way of knowing the size a game series get, every game sort of has its own reception, there is no sense of franchise. Even the hype meter doesn't go wild when you make a sequel to a high selling, beloved game. I'd like to see fans claiming for sequels of your hit franchises, absurd hype and stuff like that, maybe investors claiming for sequels. Something that lets you know you've created a huge franchise and allows you to see the effect it has on the market and in your company. Still on that topic, the game history menu is really simple and never conveys to you, in a macro sense, your body of work. It should be divided, again, into franchises, so you could easily compare how every installment did. I'd also like to see some variety on the reviews of your games and maybe a monthly bulletin with news and articles about your company. Text wise, the game is just really poor, you really have to fill in the blanks with your imagination.Most of my criticism about the game falls into what it didn't do, which I know it's unfair, but I was enjoying my playthrough so much that I really missed these features. I had to come to the point of creating a notepad file where I divided all my games in franchises with its statistics so I could have that macro point of view and could decide better which franchises to keep making games for. But besides all that, it's still a great, charming game. I totally recommend it even at full price. It's just a great little experience. Overall, 8/10Awesome little game!

												Short story:The game is overall good. Like U$D10 (max) good.Long story:The game offers lots of replayability, making you test and fail several times in order to get it right. Even with guides you will fail lots of times before getting it right.So, if a game is so replayable why would I say its good and not great?Well, the answer is that the game becomes frustrating REALLY quick. You get a note everytime you make a game, and many times you are punished without understanding why. The tutorials are good enough, but at certain point you are left alone to just discover by failing several times.My out was to check a guide to understand more deeply what was going on, you might need them too. (there is a very nice wiki for the game so dont worry!).Overall the game offers some nice gameplay with acceptable graphs and animations. Posted: April 19, 2014
												Short Review: This game has great replayability and is fun yet moderately challenging. 8/10Full Review:Game Dev Tycoon is a game that simulates you being a game dev and makind your own games. Now this first sentence maybe enough to make you want it, if it does get it, trust me. However if you are still unsure here is why you shouldn't be:-This game features you making games starting from the 1980's meaning you go throught the whole gaming history from the start of gaming jsut being a text adventure to the 3D AAA games we get today.-Your games get reviewed which adds a huge amount of replayability to the game as you really want to get that 10/10 game and feel like a genius.However this game does fall short in some aspects it's biggest being it's extremely casual gameplay and graphics. Most of the game you will be simply pulling sliders up and down and while this is not a bad thing it would be nice to maybe have seen a more advanced game making system.Overall get this game if you have ever wanted to be Game Developer or in fact just like strategy games because this game is quite a good one at that.FINAL SCORES:Sound= 7/10 Graphics=3/10 Gameplay= 7/10 Replayability=9/10 Overall= 8/10

Posted: December 17, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is a neat little simulator. The main part of the game focuses on 35 years of gaming history and important console releases (They don't have the licenses for the real names, but it's easy to work out). You start out in your garage developing games on your computer, once you have enough money you can move into an office, start to hire staff, and in time you can even get your own R&D lab.The acutal 'developing' of the games is fairly straight forward, you start with a small list of topics (fantasy, sci-fi, horror, racing etc...) more of which can be unlocked via research. Once you've picked a topic you choose a genre, there's 5 to choose from, you choose which system to develop the game for, to start off and later on once you've started building your own game engines, you can pick which engines to build on too, oh; you can also choose the 'audience' for a game too; Young, Everybody, Mature.Once you've chosen all the above, the actual development is divided into three sections. Each section has Three sliders that have different things connected to them, things like; World Design, Engine, Graphics, Sound etc... Set the sliders to what you think makes that particular game good, and there you go game made! Certain combinations of topic/genre/audience can work brilliantly in your favour to sell more copies, but on the other hand it can also lead to some absolute stinkers too. After you're game is complete and just before it's released you get a quick run down of experienced gained, and then on to the dreaded games review, which actually reflect how well the game will sell, so the reviewers pan the game you won't shift many units, likewise if it gets glowing reviews you're sure to make a good amount of money. Rinse and repeat until you game your own gaming empire. After a couple of releases you can start to research better graphics, sounds, AI, better story lines etc...The graphics and sounds aren't ground-breaking, but being a simulation of sorts, then they aren't going to be. I've left a couple of things out of this review as I'm sure you'll want a couple of surprises but; All in all Game Dev Tycoon is a nice fun little game, easy to get a grasp upon. The price asked for the game is definitely worth the money as there's hours and hours worth of play.

Posted: March 1, 2016
												I am a fan of the Greenheart-developers after playing this game. There are many similar games on the market, but I have never played one with such an interesting motive as this little gem. This game gives, in an easy way - a brief introduction to the hectic life of a game developer, along with history and progress of what is quite similar to the real gaming industry. How the different computers and consoles are being introduced during the story mode are realistic, and the way they parodied actual products from the real market was a good way to not make it too surreal. Especially for the younger audience, 'Game Dev Tycoon' proves and let's one understand that in entrepreneurship, hard work is key for success. Also loving the small, personal notes from the developers that reflects the game's objective. Cute!

Posted: January 2, 2015
												I liked this game very much. I will give it a 8/10.The story reminds me of the life of Bill Gates. You start with a "buisiness" in your garage and try to develope new games. Every game walks through 3 stages and in every one you need to decide which part of the game should be emphasised in the development, like graphics, sounds or story. For the different genres and settings there are different parts important. After yopur first game, which normaly fails, you can analyse it and therefor learn what went good and what went wrong, e.g. that the K.I. is important for a strategie game.With this imformation you develop the next one, and the next one, ....The Graphics of the game are not the best, but good enough for the idea of the game. It was fun to play and there are several ways to play it. For me the only minuses are the short real-time in which the game-time evolves and the kind of repetitive playstile due to it. Within a certain time, there are new consols etc. But you cannot use all of them, because the time between the consol generations are too short in game time. This leads to a certain pattern for your playstyle you choosed at the beginning. So an option to play a "marathon" like game would be nice.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												This game is fantastic and to prevent myself from going on and on ill just list pros and cons.Pros:+LIVE THE DREAM!+Great amount of content as far as custimizing your games engine and graphics and features+Enjoyably difficult in the early years (i found myself almost going bankrupt on four occasions during my rise to fame only to be saved by a single game that saved my company)+Humorus satire+Devlop your own console and decide specs+Great modding community Cons:-Player custimization is limited-Console appearence design is limited to just a few presets-Lack of a few key topics (shooters and beat-em ups are missing among others)-Lack of any kind of graphs or information on competitors and bestsellers.All in all 9/10 Perfect bargain, well worth the priceSide note-I believe the addition of being able to sign with a company and make exclusives would enhance the already great depth of this game also to be able to bankrupt other companies and take them over. Posted: December 29, 2014
												The game is pretty simple. You choose a game topic and a corresponding genre for it which you think results in a good combination. Next, you try to find out what areas to prioritize in game development that goes well with your chosen topic ang genre. Don't try to look at cheat sheets! Slowly master a topic/genre combination by making sequels. That is really what the game is about. Not a lot of replayability though as once you finish the campaign, the only thing that you may want to get are the achievements. Definitely pick it up when it's on sale and when you don't mind playing a short game.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Great game overall, well worth the $2 I paid it for it when it was on sale a while agoI rarely write reviews but this game is actually really fun to play and considering it came from an indie developer I'm very impressed.Here's a list of pros and cons.Pros Simple and easy to understand (tool tips pop up and explain most things, basic 'help' section also) Multiple consoles to develop for (pretty much all of them, missing a few smaller ones but still great) Lots of topics and genres to build for  Progress from small slummy garage to sexy building  Towards the end there is lots of do and research (the R&D towards the end is done very well) Some similarities to other dev games, but really becomes very unique towards the middle to the end (you can specialise your workers etc) Lots of other cool stuff along the wayCons (Not really negatives, just small things that could be improved) Time passes really quickly, would have been good if there was a speed slider, or if it took a little longer for the weeks to pass Your workers are skilled in development / technology but it seems to me that only 'graphics' is the only skill that utilises the technology attribute (Maybe I just don't quite understand who to assign to different tasks on medium / large games)  Sometimes its hard to see what will be successful by combining topics and genres (it does tell you it may be a good combination after you selected what you want, given you have researched it, however it would be good if you didn't have to go back and forth to select and reselect things Lots of trial and error in discovering what works, would be good to actually research into a topic to see if the market will like itOverall great game!

Posted: February 25, 2015
												Short story:The game is overall good. Like U$D10 (max) good.Long story:The game offers lots of replayability, making you test and fail several times in order to get it right. Even with guides you will fail lots of times before getting it right.So, if a game is so replayable why would I say its good and not great?Well, the answer is that the game becomes frustrating REALLY quick. You get a note everytime you make a game, and many times you are punished without understanding why. The tutorials are good enough, but at certain point you are left alone to just discover by failing several times.My out was to check a guide to understand more deeply what was going on, you might need them too. (there is a very nice wiki for the game so dont worry!).Overall the game offers some nice gameplay with acceptable graphs and animations. Although its extremly basic-looking it has certain attactiveness.I wouldnt pay more than U$D10, best price would be arround U$D5-7.

Posted: August 17, 2016
												Just finished this game a day ago for the first time, all I can say is, this game is absolutely addicting. I haven't played many other tycoon games before getting this one, the only other one I remember playing before this was Roller Coaster Tycoon. But if they're anything like what this game has to offer, I definitely need to get more.This is also a very challenging game, it's one of those games where in order to complete it, you really need to know what you're doing ahead of time. I can't even count how many times I've gone out of business, as even if you know the ins and outs of the gaming industry, it can still prove difficult. And that's honestly what I like about this game, it's very realistic with how a business in game development would play out.What also helps make me put more hours into the game is, while the main game only lasts around 6-7 hours, you can keep playing for as long as you want. Which not only puts more hours into the game but helps get some unlockables you didn't get during the normal playthrough as well. And that's not even getting into all the mods you can get for the game, furthering the replay value.Overall, I had a fantastic experience, and I'll definitely continue to play this game. Anyone who hasn't gotten it yet, and just wants an addicting game to play, I highly recommend it.Also, my final score was 30,301,570 in case you're wondering. Though if it wasn't for my last game, which sold over 10M units, it probably would've been a lot lower. XD

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a simple game that is far from perfect but is a good way to spend a few hours.You can develop games for consoles from the early 80's to the future which is pretty sweet.It is hard to master getting perfect ratings for your games as you will have to learn what type games work best on which console, which audience is best, and the best balance between graphics, sound and gameplay.After the games 35 year end point you can continue playing, unlocking things and perfecting your games but after that it gets boring after 40-50yrs depending on how well you're doing.It took me roughly 3 days to level up my character and employees to level 10, unlock everything and get all the achievements. It was fun and enjoyable but after the 20 hour mark it did get a bit boring and repetitive but the game is moddable and people have expanded upon and improved the game which is great for another couple of hours.Is it worth buying?that depends... if you want a simple sim to keep you entertained for a weekend then yes.if you want something that will give you months of enjoyment you're probably best trying another game.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is the first game of these developers. It is a very fun game that sort of gives you a fun inside into the life of game developers. You get to start alone develope your own games in different genres and for different systems and later you expand and can higher more people to help speed up development and create specialized people. One important and fun aspect is creating your own engine to use which will allow you to make even better games, but you will have to research the individual parts, and from my understanding you always have to make a new engine if you want to add more features to it.TL;DRProS- insight into the life of game developers.- get to experience the developmental history of videogame systems- you get to name your own games, and your own company, my 1st was Blizzard, 2nd Bethesda- many different topics and genres available- make your own engines for finetuning your games Cons/ recommendations for further development- your own people and you yourself  gain more skillpoint throught training but not developing and researching (needs to be changed imo), I recommend the mod learn by doing but it seems not to play well with other mods- there needs to be some more statistical tools like to be able to see what are your top 5 games in different categories, ratings, profit, etc.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Having clocked almost 10 hours on this game, I can say it's a highly reccomended game. Greenheart Games have painted an interesting picture on game design, by that I mean you create your own games. You begin in the 80's before NES times and during the golden era of the Commodore 64 [Called the Govodore64 in the game. TeeHee, Jokes.] and are given the task of creating a multimillion dollar game industry. This may seem hard at first, given all the options for creating a game. You'll begin with creating a very poor selling game that is pretty terrible. Then as you make more, you get better, gaining more fans and getting way more cash. By end-game you have an office with a Tech Lab and a Dev Center, making consoles and MMO's. There are secrets to that I'm not going to reveal at this time. I highly reccomend this to anyone who enjoys this kind of management game.

												A very addicting game, can fill the hours up as if they were minutes.  Despite a pretty small and familiar concept (assigning tasks to workers) something about this game really made it stand out.  Probably the polish of the graphics, the streamlined menus, or the incredible amount of replayability.  This game reminded me a lot of flash games with a similar premise like Newgrounds SIM or The McDonalds Videogame.  I suppose though some people might not like paying cash for a game that could almost be a flash game.  Either way, give it a try while it's on sale.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												This game is a truly amazing game for it's value, with lots of vanilla gameplay (8 hours) and hours more of modding and improving the game. While you might be disappointed by the lackluster gameplay towards the very end, the beginning and middle ramp up in difficulty easily and fluidly, and you never feel like you don't understand what's going on, but you do sometimes not know what to do.Will you sabotage your competitior for money, but risk the potential of it coming back to you? Or will you decide to keep your current outdated security system, and leave your building at risk?Though the game has lots of fun decisions and aspect, it also has a few issues as I've mentioned. Firstly, there's only about 3 generic soundtracks playing throughout the entire game and secondly the game at the end of it's scenarios and natural gameplay becomes unbelievably boring vanilla, and mods only fix this slightly.In all, Game Dev Tycoon is an interesting change from the average FPS or strategy. I feel like it's a natural evolution of the F2P games on mobile, with much more rewards and much less waiting, in exchange for less time to play.My score: 7.5/10

												I heard that this was the first game made by whoever created this. I must say, you should make more games, because I had a great time with this one!The music is catchy, the graphics aare "meh" (but for a game like this it doesn't matter), the gameplay is "meh" as well (but this is a strategy game, so that doesn't really qualify), but the features in this game are awesome! For the games that you create (if you did not know already that you make video games in this game) there are custom engines, many topics for games, graphical upgrades, and more! Also, a thing I really like about this game is the progression and how you slowly build a larger and larger business out of your game creation and how you are introduced to the new features as you play through.I have to admit that I usually don't play strategy games, but out of the ones I've played, this is one of the best! I give this game 7.5/10.

Posted: September 1, 2013
												This is the first game dev tycoon game out their and man is it a great game. I remember when I first got this I wasnt expecting much then after a few hours I was hungry so I said okay time to  stop and go eat. ...Wait why is it dark outside? ..What time is it ri-...HOW DID I LOSE TEN HOURS OF MY LIFE!? No really though thats how it went down the first time I tried this game. One of my biggest complaints was how the game could get laggy at the end because you had so much going on even though I don't have a horrible computer. Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game is extremely similar to Kairosoft's Game Dev Story for mobile. Not sure which one came out first so I'm not implying anything just that if you enjoy Kairosoft's GDS this is an absolute grab. If you've never played GDS read on.This is a game in which you start off as a programmer in your basement trying to put out a few games for the PC. Starting off you have a very limited selection of genres you can make and platforms you can put games out on. Over time you'll be able to expand your knowledge-base of genres and be able to put out games on multiple platforms. As you progress throughout the game you will also find yourself moving out of your basement and into proper offices and bring in NPCs to help you and feel like an actual company. You can research new genres, purchase contracts with new gaming systems, perform contract work on the side and even design your own console late in the game. You can train your employees and yourself to put a little more stats in those weak areas and pump out better games. This game has a lot of possibilities and the replayability is seemingly endless with your playthrough being dependent on the sales of your games which is not the same each time through. I love the fact that the game pays homage to all of the consoles that have been on the market with such names as TES, Gameling, Playsystem, Dreamvast, Mbox, and more. This game is still fun even when you put out failures that don't sell. Highly recommended

Posted: January 14, 2015
												Fair warning, if you are actually a game dev, or know a lot about the process, this game may just be frustrating. For instance, you have to spend time researching topics (zombies, fashion, sci-fi), and genera before you can use them.  The ones you start with appear to be random too,  so you cannot just start out saying "I want to make a zombie survival game".  Another problem, that anyone playing will have issue with, is the lack of feedback about the games.  I have several times seen an instance where I do well in the design, no bugs, and the research after says the choices were good, but I get really low reviews on it.  I know from online guides now that there are many other reasons for that, but my point is that in the game they really don't tell you that.Overall though it is a pretty fun game.  It really focuses on resource managment, but not in a number crunching spreadsheet way.  I keep coming back to it to play more, so they must have done something right.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												When you look at a game on the Store Page, one of the things you look at first is the Meta Score. At 69/100 I wasn't sure how I'd feel about this game so I waited, and waited, and waited. Finally when it went on sale last weekend I decided to get and I and so happy that i did. You get to start in the 80's with your own video game company that you get to name, and start developing your very first game. The Tutorial is extremely helpful and guides you step by step with what you need to do. As you progress through the weeks, months, and years you'll see new systems come and go for you to build your games on, just like how it's been in history. Of course you wont be developing on the ACTUAL systems like the NES by Nintendo but rather the TES by Ninvento. Everything comes and goes in the game just like it did in history. I've spent hours and hours on the game and I've been loving every minute of it. It makes you want to constantly push to make the best 10/10 games to rake in the cash so you can build bigger and bigger titles. I really hope they keep release content for this game but I'm not so sure they will. I guess only time will tell. Personally, one thing i would love to see added is the ability to customize how your offices look once you get more money, Where you buy your offices, ect. I've always been a sucker for being able to customize my games so that it feels like it's MY world and everything is how I want it. A bit like a SIMS game I suppose but that's just me. Of course the game has it's flaws here and there for instance, slider confusion, but oh well.In closing I'll say this. Don't look at this game and judge it by it's Meta Score. The Meta Score is complete Bullzhit (Pardon my English) and I honestly don't know why they post it up. I give it an 8.5 out of 10. Well Done. BUY THIS GAME.

Posted: February 9
												Short version:Loving the game, played it for too many hours in a too short timespan.Long version:The idea of the game is great, and they pulled it off really well, but there are tiny things that can start to nag at the back of your head.Cons:- It's a very short game(but it was advertised as a "small game", so that one can slide)- The combinations are mostly logical, but many don't make sense, like Casual games on PC being ---. Truck simulator is a casual game along with simulation, this game can be considered casual, Facebook games are the definition of casual. Or Comedy action - Postal 2. Dungeon Adventure is only a +. Really?- Multi-genre is almost never worth it. Unless you know from the top of your head what are the great combos for multi-genre it's not worth spending money and resources on it, given the short timespan of your game. It's better to just stick to what you know works once you even get far enough for multi-genre.- MMOs?? The maintenance costs rise so fast that you can maybe push out 2-3 AAA expansions before you'll lose more money than gain. I wanted to make a long lasting MMO, but instead had to drop it once the maintenance costs became ridiculous without much income.- Consoles. It's pretty much not worth it to make consoles. By the time you can get one out it'll probably have outdated hardware and you'll end up spending way more on it than you actually earn.- Technology/Design balance. It's not reflected well in the game that it actually matters, and there's not even a hint of what's correct. The only reason I know this is because I started looking solutions to some problems online and fount out it exists.Looking at that list it doesn't look like the game could be worth much, but other than those points it's a solid game. Micro-manage the game development, assign your team to different tasks, train your team the best for their position.Best 9 eur I've spent in a long while.

												Game Dev Tycoon is a pretty self explanatory game. You start out as a one man (or woman) game company and build your way up through the gaming industry, making games for popular and classic consoles alike.I found this game to be extremely fun and I'm now honestly working on getting the last couple achievements I have left, which will keep me going for quite some time yet. It's just so much fun to make any kinda of game that you can imagine. An Action/RPG Virtual Pet game? Sure, why not? A Simulation Game Dev game? Hmmm sounds familiar~All in all, Game Dev Tycoon is an excellent game and I'd recommend it to anyone, especially those as fascinated with the game industry as I am.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												A really addictive game in which you run your own game developing company. Although it's not really graphical, and the main focus is all on "numbers", it's still very enjoyable. There are plenty of genres to pick from as well as plenty of themes, and it actually matters to make a good link between the theme and genre you pick. Other things you get to choose are for example the platform the game will be released for, and most importantly, what are you willing to work on the most during development time (gameplay, story, graphics, and so on). As time goes by you'll have options to research new stuff, create new game engines and grow your company. The bigger it gets, the more difficult it is to manage it. The main flaw of this game is lack of other companies to compete against. We just sort of compete against ourselves- try to make the most money without going bankrupt. As good as Game Dev Tycoon is, I just see space for it being even better.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon, so far, is an entertaining and interactive game where you try to make it big as a game developer. It's not graphically superior, and it's not a music masterpiece. What it is, is a small bit of fun you can have at your leisure. It's tricky, fun, and enjoyable.Would I buy this if it wasn't part of the Summer Sale? Probably not.Do i enjoy the game when i play it? For the most part, yes. At times it seems easy, and other times insuferable, and sometimes, the gameplay seems just right. Do I regret the purchase? No. Recommended? If on sale, by all means, i would get it. If it's full price, I'd personally add it to your wishlist and wait to be notified of a sale.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												I must say. Wow. I bought this game just because i felt like playing a tycoon game I havent played yet and I'm amazed. Although the graphics and customisation is lackluster, the game itself and how its implemented are superb. I also love the little bits of humor and "admin costs" thrown in. You'll undersand if you play it.While it could use a little work in the details department, such as controlling the finer aspects of game creation (Game Pricing, MMO type games, subscription type games, offerring deals on old games rather than them just finish selling totally, competition etc) it offers a unique experience that I haven't found in any other tycoon game. During the start of the game, the developers thank you for purchasing and mention that its the first game they have created. Even if this was there 100th, this is an elegant and simplistic art work. One word can be used to describe it and that word is "Masterpiece". I can't wait for a sequel! In fact, sign me up for helping development for free! I would love to help create the sequel if theres ever going to be.You had me at hello.You can't handle the truth.Are you not entertained?YESSSS! I FINALLY GOT THE ACHIEVEMENT "TURN IT UP TO 11!" I CAN NOW STOP PLAYING THIS GAME. THANK GOD.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												A silly little game that is basically a homage to gaming development from the 80's to the present. You start as a 1-person dev team, and your goal is to make games, make money, and get fans. The basic gist of the game is quick to grasp, but I wouldn't call this game "easy to master" either. It has a rather nebulous review and scoring system that left me confused and disappointed at times when I put a gigantic amount of effort into making a good game only to see it fail at reviews. Because apparently reviews are a comparison based on your past games, so if you make a smash-hit expect to make a bunch of "meh" games for quite a while after it.It can be difficult to not go bankrupt, and since sales/reviews go together quite alot you have to develop a long-term plan of making slightly better games each time, and to not make such gigantic leaps forward that you find yourself to be a victim of your own success.Anyway, game. Is it good? It's okay. I'd say anyone who has had a long interest in gaming may want to take a peek at it, if only for a few laughs and nostalgic bits. But once you are done with it there isn't much left to do here other than kill time. Ultimately it gets on the repetitive side once you've basically unlocked everything and are just grinding your way up to try for that absurdly difficult Unobtanium achievement. Might be something to get on a sale. If nothing else, you can get funny moments playing this game, like having a Romance/Adventure game for the Game Boy being a cult classic 10/10. >_>

Posted: July 3, 2014
												I mean?  I liked it.  It's not as good as Game Dev story, though.  Very similar, for sure, but it tells a story of (your) game company more than anything.It's very simplistic and easy to figure out, though.  Bit of a rough start because nothing is really explained, but once you start figuring things out, yeah, you kind of just blast through it.My biggest gripe -- and this holds true for game dev story as well -- is that this is just a number simulator.  There really isn't anything going on that makes this experience specifically about video games.  You build some characters and they do things effectively and then you win.  Raise the numbers and then all the things.I liked it enough to play through a couple of times, though, and I suppose that's saying something.  It's a nice game to chill out with.One thing: some of the achievements for this game are super convoluted and suck to get, and a few are really, really RNG based.  I don't really like achievements that go along the lines of "just keep doing this and maybe you'll get lucky!"  Meh.Anyway, this is a pretty niche game so don't be surprised if you end up not liking it.  The entire game is, literally, about raising numbers.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												Ever since I started gaming, I've always wanted to try stepping into the shoes of one of those talented people who make games as a profession. Problem is, I'd have to go through hours and hours of dreadful tutorials of coding and meshing plus investing a respectable amount of cash in order to get my own project going. I'd also have to establish a lot of connections within the gaming community. Game Dev Tycoon skips the whole learning phase and gets you straight to the core: making games. Well... almost. While it limits your options for a game to just a genre and a few funny adjustable pillars, it does give you that authentic and exciting feel of building your own company and trying to rise up to the top of the pack. You also get to relive the history of video gaming with the rise and fall of real companies and consoles, building your titles on a wide variety of platforms from the NES to the PS4. Overall, it is a great experience for fans of video games and those who don't have the energy for making games in the real world. Just don't expect too much depth or choice in the actual creating.

Posted: August 29, 2014
												The game itself seems simple. A game that allows you to become a creator of a game. But it's so much more than just that.The goal of the game is basically to build and grow a succesful game developing corporation by creating good games, making money, hiring new workers, and researching new things to add to your games and make them better. Simple concept, but it works flawlessly.The depth of this game is surprising for that of a simple indie title, a game that basically allows you to choose any path you want as a developer. The amount of game genres, training tasks, research topics, and employees is simply amazing. You forge your own path, hire new people, and basically become the biggest game developer in the world. Sometimes, you'll go bankrupt, and have to start over. Other times, you just keep growing towards the eventual end of the game. You'd think you've experienced everything the game has to offer after one playthrough, but you'll find new things and new problems every time you play. The game is enhanced even more by its modding scene. Since they added Steam Community workshop for the game, you can download tons of different mods that can give you stuff like more consoles to sell games on, more tasks and research, money cheats, etc. Modding adds so much to this game and extends the replay value even more.In summary, Game Dev Tycoon is an amazingly crafted indie game whose goal is simply to just make games and be successful. Props to the devs, they truely have created a masterpiece.

Posted: March 3, 2016
												This game is incredibly relaxed and casual. Though that is in no way a bad thing. As a person that loves to play a lot of really engaging RPGS I find it nice to relax with Game Dev Tycoon. It has the right mix of challenge and ease. The game itself is easy to learn. Though there are a lot of challenges such as how to spend your money, what combinations of genre and game style go well together and on which platform. You also need to know when to advance your technology and when to hold off. The game has good longevity but the mid workshop really extends the life of the game. Overall if you want a really casual but challenging experience I recommend this game. This game has a very specific target audience in the management style of game and it really hits it.

Posted: March 2
												This is a particularly interesting game because, while rather simple in concept, it integrates an understanding of gaming development that is not only interesting but also informative.  As you play, you learn the different trends, information on what kinds of games go best with which consoles, and where best to focus your energy to create the best games.  Still, as with the real world, the game can prove quite challenging at moments.It is the progression of the game, I believe, that makes it so addicting.  Starting in a basement by yourself and working your way up is no easy task;  sometimes you fail before it really feels you begin.  When you get more comfortable with the trends of the game and begin to strategize, only then are you able to succeed long enough to grow your company.  As with any good game, this then raises the stakes and makes failing so much harder.I have played it through a couple of times now, and I'm trying to wait to pick it up for another round because I know it'll suck me in yet again.  It is interesting to see how every little choice can affect the outcome of the game, from which games to make, to what research should be done, to who to hire.  All in all, if you like games that make you think while giving you a large sense of control and a well-earned sense of accomplishment, I would definitely recommend this game for you.

Posted: May 19, 2015
												For a game so simple, it has so much to offer. I've played almost 30 hours of this so far. The regular game length is 5 (give or take a few) hours. Mods are a huge benefit to this game. They expand the topic list and the platforms in the game. I've had it for a year now and only just decided to write a review about it. I still play it every so often making obscene titles for my games and still getting 9s and 10s in reviews. Overall I'd give this game a rarely seen 11/10.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Brilliant little game - wholeheartedly recommend it!Fun, very moreish, great-looking, sound fx and music are a perfect fit. Overall really well-designed. I was up till 3.30 am this morning playing it, that's how addictive it is.Played a full 30-year (I believe it is) game and enjoyed it immensely.Just a few additional comments that stop me giving it 100%:- No difficulty levels- Advertising/promotion options are limited (these are much better in Game Dev Story)- Impossible to research all knowledge/do all training in the game period (many would see this as a good thing though but I do feel this aspect of the game takes a little too much time)- You need all your research points for researching new genres and developing new engines, so little is left over for training your staff- It's generally not worth investing in other platforms apart from the PC (due to very similar market share) until you unlock multi-platform tech- It's not clear from the game or the in-game hints which game dev aspects require design or tech skills - this would make a big difference!Overall, though, a super experience and for the price an absolute steal!

Posted: December 2, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is an extremely fun game and is worth the 10$ asking price, I will explain why below.Pros:It is extremely easy to play.The graphics are very well done.It simulates the video game industry very well.The platform and companies have very funny parody names.Cons:At first it can be difficult to make a decent game.They really dont have a way of giving you feedback about what you did wrong or right about your game other than that your Genre/Topic was a good or bad match, your genre/console was good or bad match and your console/target audience was good/bad match.All in all, prepare to lose track of time when playing this game, because even though it has some flaws you still have an awesome time playing.8/10, Cant wait for the sequel! - Star Games

Posted: January 29, 2014
												Remarkably fun simulation of running a game company. The randomized evolution of the various consoles and handhelds vs PCs works well. You don't know quite whats going to be popular, or what genres will work with what audiences. Figuring this out is the crux of the game, you're in a constant race to innovate without failing completely. I fired this up expecting to have an hour or two diversion and next thing I knew it was two in the morning. Does a great job of gamifying the process of making a game, which isn't quite as fun in real life. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys these types of simulations or has an interest in game development.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												Fair warning, if you are actually a game dev, or know a lot about the process, this game may just be frustrating. For instance, you have to spend time researching topics (zombies, fashion, sci-fi), and genera before you can use them.  The ones you start with appear to be random too,  so you cannot just start out saying "I want to make a zombie survival game".  Another problem, that anyone playing will have issue with, is the lack of feedback about the games.  I have several times seen an instance where I do well in the design, no bugs, and the research after says the choices were good, but I get really low reviews on it.  I know from online guides now that there are many other reasons for that, but my point is that in the game they really don't tell you that.Overall though it is a pretty fun game.  It really focuses on resource managment, but not in a number crunching spreadsheet way.  I keep coming back to it to play more, so they must have done something right.

All in all an enjoyable game and i recommend it just dont think you'll be playing it for months on end. 8/10

												Not sure if it delivers an authentic experience or not after all...>Founded "Ahoy Games" as Shaun Morray.>Somehow made a couple hits.>Decided to make No One's Lie for PS1 or something like that.>Hyped it up.>It flopped into a 6/10ish>Created more games. Bunch of hits from time to time.>Completed the game on the first go with a score of 39,734,414------------------------------------------------------------------ON A SERIOUS NOTE;PROS:- Nice, simple art style. Game could easily be only text-based, but I appreciate the visuals a lot.- Passes time immensly- Very cheap- Lovely message from the creators in-game :)- ModsCONS:- Difficulty is decent for the first playthrough. Wish I could turn it up though. (Maybe I'll find a mod)- Limited replayability. (it is there, just not enough)- Also wish the marketshare % would be a little dynamic, changing from playthrough to playthrough. Would add a bunch to replayability.- Few features like competition with other studios or maybe even multiplayer would be great (for the next game/addon/version) Wish they were there.Incredibly addictive and enjoyable 9 hours. Definitely worth the price, don't even need a sale. The CONS are truly minor opposed to the genuinely enjoyable time to be had with this game. Will definitely come back to this some time.

												For a game so simple, it has so much to offer. I've played almost 30 hours of this so far. The regular game length is 5 (give or take a few) hours. Mods are a huge benefit to this game. They expand the topic list and the platforms in the game. I've had it for a year now and only just decided to write a review about it. Posted: May 16, 2015
												Brilliant little game - wholeheartedly recommend it!Fun, very moreish, great-looking, sound fx and music are a perfect fit. Overall really well-designed. I was up till 3.30 am this morning playing it, that's how addictive it is.Played a full 30-year (I believe it is) game and enjoyed it immensely.Just a few additional comments that stop me giving it 100%:- No difficulty levels- Advertising/promotion options are limited (these are much better in Game Dev Story)- Impossible to research all knowledge/do all training in the game period (many would see this as a good thing though but I do feel this aspect of the game takes a little too much time)- You need all your research points for researching new genres and developing new engines, so little is left over for training your staff- It's generally not worth investing in other platforms apart from the PC (due to very similar market share) until you unlock multi-platform tech- It's not clear from the game or the in-game hints which game dev aspects require design or tech skills - this would make a big difference!Overall, though, a super experience and for the price an absolute steal!

Posted: September 7, 2014
A nice piece that grants a tiny look into what game development breaks down to.Don’t get me wrong, this game is in no way a correct and accurate depiction of actual video game development. But as most models are a abstract and minimalist representation of an actual situation or process, this game truly is a great model of game development. The game mechanic is very easy to understand and also easy to use. The graphic style is nice and pretty but not fancy. The game has a high replay value, because even though the first two thirds of the game are easily predictable (if one knows the outcomes of the video game industry history), the outcome of each single game you create is completely different.If one want to learn a little bit about the history of game development and have a first whiff of what might come in handy if one want’s to become part of the industry, this game is a great start.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												Extremely addictive and immersive. It tells a story about the turn of the century in which you are an independent studio and you alone decide whether or not your studio becomes a staple in the devs of the next generation or yesterday's news.Pros:-immersive-original-true to the video game industry-versatility in what you want your dev team to be-30+ hours of quality entertainment-it's only 10$ so you get bang for your buck-developed by a small independent studio (not bad for a starting game)Cons:-limited replayability-there is no way to know whether or not your video game will be successfulthe only way to learn what works is with trial and error. final score -7/10 9/10 if there was a way to boost research points, however you can get research points (limited) for doing contract workwithout this feature the research mechanic seems lackluster.10/10 if you could do surveys for your target audience to see what they wouldlike in the game you're developing. Must have.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												This game is too shallow and simplistic at times. Like, I am learned in the history of gaming to a certain extent, so it's fun to use this knowledge. But I really would like to turn on some kind of randomization (like maybe the Dreamcast could be a hit in an alternate universe!) on replays for starters. Some stuff is probably flushed out in the modding community, but I don't have time to dig through all that to get the game I want.I also wish there were more opportunities to be creative: write taglines, interview answers, game descriptions, reply to fans... stuff like that. Even though it's impossible for a sim game to "score" stuff like that, I always like when sim games have this kind of creative input allowed.Still, I played through this game like three times (and I don't replay games any more) so it's pretty doggone fun.

It's quirky, it's a weird concept, and I noticed on the second day that IT HAS MOD SUPPORT (although not through steam workshop). Even now, I'm still confused with myself over what exactly draws me to keep playing it.All I can say for sure is that it is a lot of fun. Knowing how much fun it is now, I wish I had purchased it a long time ago.

Posted: August 31, 2013
												While I had a good time and even recommended this game, this is NOT a game for everyone. Some people by definition will not consider this a good game.This is really at it's core an observation game. The majority of gameplay is looking at numbers go up so you can get high review numbers so you can get bigger money numbers, so you can make bigger games that will get even bigger numbers to go up. Rince and repeat.It isn't the most uninvolved game I've ever played, but after how long I've spent away from this game, I notice it is not as "fun" as it once seemed.Does that mean you shouldn't get this game? Of course not, just look how much time I spent with this overall, if this game was not fun, I wouldn't have put that much time into this game.I really hope Green Heart gives this game a sequel one day, there is potential for a great game, they just didn't go the extra miles to uncover that potential.

Posted: September 7, 2014
A nice piece that grants a tiny look into what game development breaks down to.Don’t get me wrong, this game is in no way a correct and accurate depiction of actual video game development. But as most models are a abstract and minimalist representation of an actual situation or process, this game truly is a great model of game development. The game mechanic is very easy to understand and also easy to use. The graphic style is nice and pretty but not fancy. The game has a high replay value, because even though the first two thirds of the game are easily predictable (if one knows the outcomes of the video game industry history), the outcome of each single game you create is completely different.If one want to learn a little bit about the history of game development and have a first whiff of what might come in handy if one want’s to become part of the industry, this game is a great start.

Posted: September 17, 2016
Overall vote: 6.5"Game Dev Tycoon" is a simulator that knows how to be appreciated, although it lacks, in some parts, of quality and depth. You will impersonate the classic "nerd" of the early era of videogames, busy developing his first games in his garage (where you can see a "DeLorean" under a tarp). With the early successes, we are destined to grow up until we will be a world-renowned software house, with various employees and millions of fans.GAMEPLAY: 7 Quite simple and immediate; A lot of topics, researches and platforms; Some parts aren't so well developed, such as the management of your company (you can hire only six  employees, very few to develop AAA games IMHO); There are no competitors; The evaluation of the games is not exactly brilliantGRAPHIC: 5 Pleasant cartoony graphic; Little animations; Minimal and undeveloped game design;MUSIC, SOUNDS, EFFECTS: 6 Basic and monotonous soundtrack; Common sound effects;LONGEVITY: 6.5 It has a quite good replayability, depending on whether you want to pursue a career as developers of action games (console or PC), or GDR, or casual, etc. etc. It takes time to discover every possibile combo between Topics, Audience, Platforms, etc.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is an extremely fun game and is worth the 10$ asking price, I will explain why below.Pros:It is extremely easy to play.The graphics are very well done.It simulates the video game industry very well.The platform and companies have very funny parody names.Cons:At first it can be difficult to make a decent game.They really dont have a way of giving you feedback about what you did wrong or right about your game other than that your Genre/Topic was a good or bad match, your genre/console was good or bad match and your console/target audience was good/bad match.All in all, prepare to lose track of time when playing this game, because even though it has some flaws you still have an awesome time playing.8/10, Cant wait for the sequel! - Star Games

												This game will definitely not appeal to everyone, but I loved it :D It is great to play through, trying to combine different elements in game development to make the best game possible, there are flaws as to the fact that once you find all of the great combos, you sort of finish the game, but watching your money pile up and your studio become bigger is satisfying enough to keep playing until you finish it. Totally worth the price, sometimes sort of stutters and sometimes when you click buttons they dont work until you click them 5 times, hope the developers release some updates to fix these small glitches :D A great game recommended to anyone who is either curios about game development and/or a fan of tycoons :D

Posted: January 30, 2014
												I wish I could play some more before writing this review but the game is stuck in my head and I must let people know. This game is both excellent and challenging.I initially felt it would be an absolute breeze like other money sim type  game. Once you get the rythm and flow, making money is super simple and you basically cannot lose at that point.Not so much in this game. The difficult curve is absolutly appropriate but a tad unforgiving. I made a hit game in my 4th year (gametime) and moved to the bigger office and life was good, for about 3 years. I could not maintain the momentum to keep my business running and thus I fell into bankruptcy.It was a blast. Not the bankruptcy but the challenge of how to make a hit game which is not as easy as it sounds. There are a lot of nuances and tweaks that can make or break a game.It makes you think and strategize over the whole course of the game. Each descision will flow through the entire course of the game. I would highly recommend to anyone who likes sim games.

Simple and clean gameplay, immediate interface. If you are a "true" and old gamer..is impossible to not smile to see old console..like sega mega driver..or commodore 64..and making games for those console. second point is..if you like that kind of games, Game Dev tycoom is a must.
